Sara Noemy P. G. resides in the town of Colon, located in the department of La Libertad. She is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters, Angelina (age 8) and Stefany (age 6). Two years ago, Sara started her business with the idea of helping her husband with the family expenses. She has a store in her home where she sells household consumer products. Although her sales are stable, Sara does not have the necessary capital to restock her business. For this reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can continue increasing her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase inventory to restock her business

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren D. is a 45-year-old single mother of two children. She currently lives with her 14-year-old son in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter is 19 years old and is a student in the National University of Mongolia in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Purevsuren has been running a small meat retail stall in the local food market for the last nine years. She usually purchases mutton and beef at wholesale prices and sells in small pieces to local customers. She says that she is very experienced in the business and has her own loyal customers who always purchase their meat supply from her.

The business has been stabilized and she further notes that she is still working hard to make sure that she will be able to make enough money to pay her daughter's tuition.

She requests a loan to purchase more meat for her business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: to purchase more meat for her business

loans.name: Santos Alexander

texts.es: Santos Alexander H. P. de 35 años de edad, originario del departamento de Morazán, vive con su familia que la compone, su esposa y sus tres hijos, Joanna de 9 años, Wilber de 4 años y Jennifer de 12 meses. El departamento de Morazán se caracteriza mucho por su clima caliente y por la variedad de sitios turísticos que se pueden encontrar, Santos aprovecha al máximo de su entorno ya que se dedica a la venta de artesanías la cuales el fabrica desde su casa, las artesanías de Santos las vende de manera ambulante y son compradas por muchos turistas extranjeros o nacionales, la demanda en las artesanías de Santos ha ido incrementando, es por esa razón que ahora el solicita de un crédito con el cual, pueda adquirir mayor cantidad de insumos y así aumentar la producción de sus artículos.
texts.en:
Santos Alexander H. P. is 35 years old and a native of the department of Morazán. His family consists of his wife and three children: Joanna (age 9), Wilber (age 4), and Jennifer (age 12 months). Morazán is known for its warm climate and numerous tourists sites. Santos takes advantage of these conditions by selling handicrafts he produces at home. He sells his goods as a street merchant to tourists, both foreign and domestic. Demand for his work is increasing, so he is requesting a loan in order to acquire supplies in bulk and increase production of these items.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies needed for making handicrafts

loans.name: Kojoki

texts.en:
Kojoki B. is currently in the business of selling sugar, rice and soap in a shop, and is requesting a loan to purchase other items such as paraffin, bags of beans, etc. to sell.  Kojoki is 28 years old and is married to an accountant. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a larger store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase paraffin, bags of beans, etc. to sell

loans.name: Fidel Ángel

texts.es: Fidel Ángel M. P. originario del departamento de La Unión, vive junto a su hija Nubia de 18 años de edad, estudiante de bachillerato. A sus 56 años de edad sigue luchando por darle lo mejor a su hija, brindándole una estabilidad económica y así ella pueda continuar con sus estudios, Fidel se dedica a la crianza de cerdos desde el terreno que posee su hogar, los cerdos son engordados y cuidados por meses para luego comercializar su carne, es así como se gana la vida don Fidel que en esta oportunidad esta solicitando de un crédito con el pueda incrementar su crianza de cerdos.
texts.en:
Fidel Ángel M. P. is originally from the department of La Unión. He lives with his 18 year old daughter Nubia, who is studying for her bachelor’s degree. At 56 years of age, Fidel still struggles to provide the best for his daughter. In order to bring financial stability so that she can continue her education, Fidel raises pigs on land that he possesses. The animals are fattened and cared for in the months prior to being sold for their meat. Since this is his livelihood, Fidel is requesting a loan so that he can raise more pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acquire more pigs to raise

loans.name: Olegaria

texts.en:
Olegaria C. is from the village of Liposong, Ozamiz City. She is 46 years old and married with 6 adult children. To make a living, she raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting "mais" (corn) for sale. Olegaria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Olegaria joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Olegaria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Olegaria is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP; she will use the money to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Olegaria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Serjan

texts.en:
Serjan O. is 35-years-old and the father of four children. He resides in Bayan-Olgii province, one of Mongolia's western provinces, with his children and wife. Three of his four children are secondary school students; the fourth is a 1-month-old baby, for whom Serjan's wife stays home to care. 

Serjan has been engaged in small businesses since 2005. He started with a clothing retail business and subsequently switched to a fuel retail business in 2008. He purchases fuel from fuel-trucks that pass through his town to carry fuel from Russia to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He purchases the fuel at a lower price and then sells it to local car owners at a lower price than local fuel stations. Since he offers a better rate than local fuel stations, he receives fuel orders from his customers in advance. Additionally, he repairs broken cars and sells them at profit and runs a small chicken farm at home. His wife takes care of the chicken farm and sells the eggs in local stores. 

He is requesting a loan so that he can purchase some feed for his chicken farm and have more capital with which to purchase fuel for his customers' orders.

About XacBank:

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia; additionally, it has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: purchasing more chicken feed and fuel

loans.name: Mavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Mavy S. lives in the Thmei village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates both rice and vegetables. On this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy farming supplies for growing rice and vegetables. Thus, she is requesting for a loan for this purpose.

Her husband, Mr. Arn Roeun, is a construction worker. Mrs. Mavy S. is 49 years old and the mother of two children who attend the local school. Her husband appears in the picture with her.

loans.use: Buy farming supplies for her growing rice and vegetables

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local beer and is requesting a loan to buy other items like soda, water, and milk powder to sell. Dudu is 25 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar and restaurant.

About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy items like soda, water, and milk powder to sell

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en: Prisca S. is 30 years old and owns a top-ranking beauty salon. She offers manicures, pedicures, weaving, and other treatments to her customers. She has been doing this for the last five years. She has one employee and does face challenges like a lack of stock of accessories and strong competition from similar businesses. Apart from this business, she also sells old and new clothes. She is using her 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan to buy a flat iron, hair curling tongs, and chemicals. She is looking forward to opening a hairdressing training school at which she will be the beauty instructor. Prisca is single with an eleven year old daughter and describes herself as hardworking and talented.

loans.use: To buy a flat iron, hair curling tongs, and treatment chemicals

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo G., who is known in his community as “Danny,” is 38 years old and is married to Myrna. They are blessed with one son named Danny Boy G., seven years old. They live in Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. They aim to be successful in life to give their son a better future. Despite the hardships and difficulties in life, they strive harder to earn a living.

Farming is their way of making a living. They till their land twice a year to plant rice and vegetables. They are also engaged in hog raising to earn additional income. They want to expand their plantation to have a plentiful harvest and to improve their piggery by increasing their livestock. Since they don’t have enough capital, they want to borrow from Kiva lenders the amount of 10,000 Philippine pesos to be used in acquiring the needed materials for the maintenance of their crop production and piggery. They hope that through patience and sacrifice, they will achieve their goal. They believe that “God is merciful to those who are honest and faithful.”

loans.use: Additional capital for his hog raising business

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana J. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items like fish, groundnut paste, and rice to sell. Diana is 30 years old and is married to a is a fisherman. She has 3 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy items like fish, groundnut paste, and rice to sell

loans.name: Ide

texts.en:
Ide P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Ide is 30 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children. About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
“Do your work well and the blessings will be yours.” That's an inspiring quotation shared by Genoveva D. of Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. After her college education, she married Federico D. and they are blessed with three children. They want all of their children to be successful in their chosen professions so that they will be employed someday.

The major source of their income is through farming. They till their parcel of land twice a year. They plant rice, corn and some vegetables. Genoveva is also engaged in selling different snacks and peanut butter in their village to earn additional income. Due to the high cost of commodities and school expenditures, she wants to borrow additional capital from the Kiva lenders amounting to 10,000.00 Philippine pesos to increase her capital in order to improve her small business. She believes that with her patience and sacrifice, she will be able to improve her small business and support the schooling of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital for her food production business

loans.name: Alverlyn

texts.en:
Alverlyn V. is 32 years old and resides in the village of Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. After high school, she married Mr. Marcelo V., Jr. and they are blessed with two children. They aim to uplift their standard of living to give their children a better future. They endure hardships and difficulties in earning a living for their survival and for the schooling of their children.

The major source of their income is farming. They cultivate their farm by planting rice and vegetables twice a year. Furthermore, Alverlyn sells fruits and vegetables in their village to help her husband in gaining income. She wants to improve this small business but she had inadequate capital. That is why she wants to borrow an amount of 5,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders to be used in improving her small business. She is happy and thankful because she has the opportunity to improve her small business with this financial assistance.

loans.use: Additional capital for buying and selling fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Lita A. is from the village of Matugas Alto, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Lita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lita owns and operates a business venture selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making "puto" (rice cakes) and other delicacies for sale. Lita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through these activities.

In 2007, Lita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lita is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Lita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for making rice cakes and other delicacies

loans.name: Wojje Azeewo, Kayunga Group

texts.en:
Margaret K. is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is a responsible married lady with school-going children. She also takes care of other orphans, including paying their school fees. With her husband, she farms bananas, maize, beans, cassava and sweet potatoes to sell. They have been able to buy a pickup truck to transport their produce to the market, plus they rent out the truck to others to bring in extra income. Additionally, Margaret and her husband own a motorcycle business and all these businesses help to run her home.

Margaret is requesting a loan to buy more quality seeds for the farm and to repair her motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying quality seeds for agriculture

loans.name: Margaret Wariara

texts.en:
Margaret N. is married to Moses and they have three children: Carolyne, 9, Sharon, 7, and Angel, 2.

Margaret was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, through existing clients and she is servicing her second loan. She has been selling new clothes for two years. She intends to use the loan to add more stock of clothes and prepare for the festive season (Christmas).

Margaret's business is in a small market and she relies on the customers who frequent the market. With the extra profits she anticipates getting, she intends to add more stock into the business. 

Margaret's hope is to own a big boutique as she believes she is hardworking.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock of new clothes for sale

loans.name: Shaiym's Group

texts.en:
Shaiym is the leader of this group. Shaiym lives in a rural town. Together with her husband, she has raised four children. Her husband is engaged in trading at the market. As for the children, the elder sons, who are 34 and 29, make their living by working as taxi drivers. A daughter, 26, is a seamstress. The youngest son, 22, is a welder. 

About 10 years ago, Shaiym got an idea to start raising cattle. She consulted with her husband and children and they decided to give this idea a try and purchased some sheep and a cow. After a short period of time, they understood that this was an excellent business as it was profitable and economical. Since that time, Shaiym has received a lot of profit as she has been selling milk daily and selling sheep when needed. 

Having these children, Shaiym is already a happy mother and could easily spare herself from any kind of concerns or problems. However, she has been the one who has brought these children up to be hardworking young people. Now Shaiym is 56 years old. She is actively occupied with increasing the total population of her cattle and sells 15 liters of milk per day. This brings her around $105 per month. Moreover, all her children strive to help their mother after work to take care of cattle. Shaiym does not have any difficulties dealing with her livestock. Shaiym needs a loan to buy one more cow. 

Shaiym’s partners are: 

Asel, 22, is married. Her husband is a welder. Asel raises livestock and sells milk. She needs this loan to buy two or three sheep.

Aigul, 40, has three children. Her husband works at a construction site. Aigul tailors woolen shoes and sells them at a fair. Aigul hopes to buy some sheep with this loan.

Rapat, 30, is the wife of a taxi driver. Rapat works as a seamstress. She has applied for this loan to buy one calf. 

Shaiym and her partners have some savings to add to the loans to be able to make their purchases.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Khoeun K. lives in the Prey Run village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a well builder. His wife, Mrs. Nob Naet (pictured here), is a pig breeder. Her pig-breeding business is going well, so she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food. Thus, Mr. Khoeun K. is asking for a loan for this purpose.

This couple has four children; three are enrolled in the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: Purchase more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Belki Esmeralda

texts.es: Belki Esmeralda G. C.  de 24 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad. Belki vive con su esposo y su pequeño hijo llamado Roberto de 12 meses. Belki es una mujer muy trabajadora se dedica a su negocio donde elabora pupusas y panes con pollo, los cuales vende desde su casa, ahora desea ampliar sus ventas con un nuevo negocio de venta de pólvora, que es demandada en época navideña, es por ello que solicita de un crédito para poder comprar pólvora e insumos para su negocio.
texts.en:
Belki Esmeralda G. C. is 24 years old and a resident of Ciudad Arce in the department of La Libertad. She lives with her husband and her 12 month old son named Roberto. Belki is a hardworking woman who makes pupusas and panes con pollo (a traditional Salvadoran chicken dish), which she sells out of her home. Now she wants to increase her sales with a new business selling fireworks, which are in demand during the holiday season. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy fireworks and ingredients for her food business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for preparing food & fireworks to sell for the holidays

loans.name: Leah Wambui

texts.en:
Leah K. is married to Stanley and they have no children yet. They live within Nairobi city.

Leah has been selling rice for five years. Her business is in a semi-rural area with a large population. Her other source of income is dairy farming, and she intends to use her loan, along with her own savings, to buy a dairy cow thus diversifying her income base. With the extra profits from her business, she will add more stocks of rice. Leah was introduced to Kiva partner KADET through existing clients and she is requesting her third loan.

Leah's future hope is to own several dairy cows. She believes that she is focused on her goals.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Jenishgul's Group

texts.en:
Jenishgul is the leader of her borrowing group. She is forty four years old and is the mother of two children, an eighteen-year-old daughter and a fourteen-year-old son. To support their family, Jenishgul’s husband works as a taxi driver. In the summer he switches to working at a private construction business. Their daughter is a junior in college and she studies there on a state scholarship. Their son is in the seventh grade in middle school.

Jenishgul buys and sells fruit such as oranges, bananas, etc.  Since childhood, she has always liked exotic fruit. She always dreamed of having a shop of her own where she could sell all kinds of fruit. Her dream came true ten years ago, when she finally opened her own fruit shop. It took her great effort and patience to do so but it was worth it. Since then, Jenishgul has bought herself a car and some equipment for her home.

Jenishgul’s husband helps her haul the fruit. Now Jenishgul’s monthly income is about $465. She has applied for this loan to buy apples in the Yssykkul region. As apples of this region are well known, she believes that this purchase will help her increase her turnover and make more money. In the autumn of 2010, Jenishgul's daughter will get married. Jenishgul has already started to save money for her daughter’s dowry. Beyond the dowry, Jenishgul wants to surprise her daughter with a gift of bedroom furniture. 

Jenishgul has three partners in this group loan: 

Damira, 56, is divorced. She has three children. Two of her daughters are married and live separately, and her son is in the sixth grade. Damira raises cattle. She hopes buy a cow with the money from this loan.

Sinat, 60, and her husband are retired. They have raised three children. Sinat keeps cows and sells twenty liters of milk a day. Sinat needs this loan to buy a calf for breeding.

Gulzat, 30, has one ten-year-old daughter. Her husband is a builder. Gulzat works as a saleswoman in a small shop. Gulzat needs this loan to buy more goods for her shop. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy apples for resale at a fruit shop.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline L., nicknamed "Vangie," lives at Barangay San Nicolas, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcya. She and her husband, George L., are blessed with five children. Despite hardships and difficulties in life, they strive to improve their living conditions and to ensure the schooling of their children.

Her husband works in the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) to earn his living, while Vangie is engaged in running a sari-sari (general store) to supplement her husband's income. She wants to increase her business's income, but her capital is not sufficient; thus, she wants to borrow from Kiva lenders a loan amounting to Php 6,000 in order to strengthen her capital and improve her small business.

loans.use: To use as capital for improving her small sari-sari store

loans.name: Nary's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Nary H. is a group leader of four members who all live in the Kshach village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate vegetables. Now she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. Thus, she is asking for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Chuong Oun, is a construction worker. This couple has four children who attend the local school.

loans.use: Buy vegetable seeds

loans.name: Serikbol

texts.en:
Serikbol S. is 38 years old and lives with his wife, their five children, and his elderly father in the province of Bayan-Olgii, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His wife stays at home in order to take care of her father-in-law and the children, whose ages range from five to 14. Serikhbol supports this large family through his business.

Serikbol is a talented craftsman, following in the footsteps of his father, who was also once a well-known craftsman in the town. Serikbol makes many kinds of items, such as various accessories for horse riding, traditional music instruments, and traditional home furniture. His wife sometimes visits the local market and sells his crafts. She usually offers the instruments and accessories in exchange for livestock and other basic goods that the family needs.

Serikbol dreams of having his own small-scale craftsman production endeavor, where he would like to be able to make instruments and crafts with more efficient technology. He and his wife hope to be financially able to send their eldest son to a university in a few years.

He requests a loan to purchase iron and wood materials for his crafts business.

loans.use: To purchase iron and wood for his crafts business

loans.name: Katherine

texts.en:
Katherine T. is the loving wife of Mr. Harold T. of Barangay San Nicolas, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with three school-aged children: Harold T. Jr., Henson Paul T., and Harine Mae T.. They want their children to become successful in their chosen professions and have a better future.

Katherine manages a small sari-sari store at home while her husband uses their tricycle to earn an income. Being an industrious couple, they are able to earn an income of 1,000 PHP a week, which they use to provide for their basic needs and pay their children's tuition fees. They want to increase their income so they can save for their future, but they have inadequate capital. Therefore, Katherine wants to borrow 6,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to improve her sari-sari store and maintain their tricycle. She hopes that, with this financial assistance, they are able to improve their small businesses through patience and sacrifice.

loans.use: To improve sari-sari store and maintain tricycle

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
“Success is at the end of every sacrifice”; that's the encouraging motto Antonio D. of Brgy. San Nicolas, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya follows. He is now 55 years old and still single. He chose to remain single because he wants to take care of his parents who are now old and weak.

He owns and manages a small beauty parlor offering haircuts, pedicures and manicures to his friends, neighbors, and people in the community who need his service. Through his patience and sacrifices, he is able to earn a net income of Php 3,000.00 a month which goes to satisfying their basic needs and allows him to save some for their future. He wants to continue and improve this business but he doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, he wants to borrow the amount of Php 6,000.00 to increase his capital to improve his small business. He hopes that with patience and sacrifice, he can improve his business and increase his income.

loans.use: Additional capital for improving his beauty salon

loans.name: Zamira's Group

texts.ru:
Тойгонбаева Замира – лидер данной группы. Замире сорок шесть лет. Она в разводе. Замира её дети живут в г. Кант. Всего их у неё пятеро. Старшему сыну двадцать шесть. Он работает строителем. Ещё одному сыну двадцать пять. Он зарабатывает себе на жизнь работая грузчиком. Двадцати – двух летняя дочка работает торговым агентом в агентстве недвижимости. Следующему сыну шестнадцать лет. Он работает в винном цехе «Кантвино». Самой младшей дочери всего восемь лет. Она учится в третьем классе.  Замира работает в кожном диспансере. Но помимо этого у неё имеется ещё кое-какая живность, которая осталась ей от мужа. Муж Замиры при разводе проявил великодушие и не стал оспаривать ничего из всего нажитого хозяйства. Более того, скот, который у них имелся, также принадлежал ему, но он и его тоже оставил Замире и детям. Замира обратилась за кредитом с целью купить дойную корову на увеличение поголовья скота. А также на оставшуюся часть кредита купить стройматериалы и достроить дом. Замира вместе с детьми строит большой дом из десяти комнат. 

У Замиры пять партнёров по группе:

Турапову Айбеку сорок пять лет. Жена Айбека - швея. Сам Айбек – строитель в «Кантвино». У Айбека пятеро детей. Чтобы прокормить семью Айбек, также держит скот. Жена и дети помогают. Айбек нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить корову. 

Разакуловой Жийдегул тридцать лет. Муж Жийдегул – строитель. Жийдегул продаёт картошку и другие виды овощей на дому. У Жийдегул четверо детей. Все ходят в школу. Старшему сын помогает Жийдегул торговать. Жийдегул нужен кредит, чтобы купить тёлку.

Кадыр кызы Айгул тридцать один год. У неё двое детей. Муж Айгул – строитель. Айгул работает продавцом – консультантом. Айгул обратилась за кредитом с целью купить стельную тёлку. Айгуль хочет увеличить живность и за счёт неё покрывать расходы семьи.

Жумабек кызы Аиде тридцать четыре. Аида – мать четверых детей. Муж Аиды работает механизатором на предприятии «Кыргыз Алтын». Аида растит детей, но также продаёт молоко, сметану и кислое молоко. Аиде нужен кредит, чтобы купить корову. 

Асановой Тамаре пятьдесят лет. Она разведена. Тамара разводит скот и сдаёт молоко. У Тамары трое детей. Дети уже работают и помогают матери ухаживать за скотом. Тамаре нужен кредит. Она хочет приобрести гравий, песок для стройки дома, пока цены не поднялись.

  --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Zamira T. is the leader of this group. Zamira is forty-six. She is divorced. Zamira and her children live in the city of Kant. She has five children. The eldest is twenty-six. He is a construction worker. Another son is twenty-five. He earns his living as a loader. Zamira's twenty-two year old daughter works as a sales agent in a real-estate agency. The next son is sixteen. He works at the "Kantvino" winery. The youngest daughter is only eight years old. She is in third grade. Zamira works at a dermatology dispensary, but she also has some livestock that her was left over from her husband. Zamira's husband was generous and did not dispute any of their household. Moreover, the livestock they had also belonged to him, but he left it to Zamira and the children. Zamira is asking for the loan in order to buy a milking cow and increase the number of her livestock. With the remainder of the credit she plans to buy building materials and finish building the house. Zamira and her children are building a big ten-room house.

Zamira has five partners in the group:

Aibek T. is forty-five. His wife is a seamstress. Aibek himself is a construction worker at the "Kantvino" winery. Aibek has five children. In order to feed his family Aibek keeps some livestock. His wife and children help him. Aibek needs a loan to buy a cow.

Jiidegul R. is thirty years old. Jiidegul's husband is a construction worker. Jiidegul sells potatoes and other vegetables from home. Jiidegul has four children, they all go to school. The oldest son helps her Jiidegul to sell potatoes. Jiidegul needs the loan to buy a heifer.

Aigul K. is thirty-one. She has two children. Aigul's husband is a construction worker. Aigul works as a sales consultant. Aigul is asking for the loan to buy a cow with a calf. Aigul wants to increase her livestock to give the family an extra income to cover their expenses.

Aida J. is thirty-four. Aida is the mother of four. Aida's husband works as a machine operator at the "Kyrgyz Altyn" factory. Aida raises the children but also sells milk, sour cream, and sour milk. Aida needs the loan to buy a cow.

Tamara A. is fifty. She is divorced. Tamara breeds livestock and sells milk. She has three children. The children are already working and helping their mother to take care of the livestock. Tamara needs a loan. She wants to purchase gravel and sand to build a house before the prices go up.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cow and pay for building materials for home repairs

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida C. is from the village of Dinas, Sinacaban,Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Zenaida is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of basic products such as shampoo, nescafe, toothpaste, soap, and dried goods in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Zenaida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie P. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 44 years old. Elsie is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Elsie owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ground pork and beef products known as "longganisa" in the local community. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elsie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Elsie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en: T. Byambasuren is 53 years old and lives with her daughter in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. She operates a garment making business with the help of her daughter in her town. Byambasuren started her business in 1990 with 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD). Over the years she has managed her business quite successfully and built a loyal customer base that frequently buy her hand-made clothes. With nearly 20 years experience as a seamstress, Byambasuren produces quality products and is trusted by her customers. Today, her working capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD).  Byambasuren is a hardworking businesswoman and has many plans for her business. She says, "I hope to expand my business in the near future." She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~280 USD) loan to purchase fabrics and materials to sew more clothes.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Lyne

texts.en:
Through patience and sacrifice, Lyne M. was able to graduate from college with a BS in nursing. Currently, she is happily married to Emerald M.. They are gifted with two children named Mark Jeremy M. and Maye Jeanne M.. Being parents, they are concerned for their children's future and strive hard to earn enough money to support their studies.

Her husband is a member of the Barangay Council in their village and uses their motorcycle to earn income while Lyne works as a government employee in Bayombong. Since their income only covers their basic needs and allowances of their children, Lyne wants to borrow Php6,000 from KIVA lenders to be used in the maintenance of their motorcycle. She believes that they can earn more money and finance their children's schooling with this financial assistance.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of their motorcycle

loans.name: Purevjav

texts.en:
C. Purevjav is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His twin sons are 4 years old and in kindergarten, and his daughter, Azjargal, is one year old. Purevjav operates a wooden product making business in his town with the help of his wife. He started his business in 2000 with capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD), and has made much progress with his business over the years. Purevjav is very hardworking and attributes his success to his good accounting and record keeping practices. Today, his working capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). Purevjav has many plans for his business's future. He says, "I want to expand my business as soon as possible." He is requesting a 580,000 tugrug (~400 USD) loan to purchase materials used in woodworking.




About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: to purchase materials used in woodworking.

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: G. Martine est née en 1979 à Bopa, au Bénin. Mariée à HOUNHOUI Hector, Martine est mère de trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Martine vit avec son mari et ses enfants depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Adogléta à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Martine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Martine n'a jamais fréquenté ; c'est pourquoi afin de subvenir à ses besoins, Martine vend divers produits (conserves, biscuits, cube, piment, bicarbonate de sodium, riz, huile végétale, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Martine s'approvisionne. Martine mène cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année, et est à son neuvième crédit. Martine a toujours bien remboursé ses crédits. Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir davantage son commerce, Martine sollicite ce neuvième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Martine G. was born in 1979 in Bopa, in Benin. She's married to Hector HOUNHOUI and the mother of three children, out of whom some attend school. For about ten years, Martine has been living with her husband and her children in the Adogléta neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She helps her husband with the family expenses. Martine never attended school, and to provide for herself, sells various products (canned food, biscuits, bouillon cubes, chili pepper, sodium bicarbonate, rice, vegetal oil, etc) at her house. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international market in Benin. Martin has been running this business for about ten years, and is seeking her ninth loan. She always repaid her loans without problems. To bolster her working capital and expand her business, she's seeking this ninth loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy canned food, biscuits, bouillon cubes, chili pepper, sodium bicarbonate, rice, vegetal oil, etc

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel and Arsenio L. of Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya, are striving to earn a living to support their three children. Despite the current economic crisis, they have a strong faith and determination to be successful in the future through patience and hard work.

Within their village, Maricel and Arsenio cultivate their small parcel of land by planting rice and some vegetables. Since harvesting takes a long time, Maricel also sells meat, frozen foods, and barbecued food in front of their house to earn an additional income. Since her capital is small, she can only earn a net income of 1,500 PHP a month. For this reason, Maricel wants to borrow 8,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to increase her capital and acquire more products to be sold in her village.

loans.use: As additional capital to acquire more products to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith C. lives in Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. After finishing her high school studies, she married George C., and they are blessed with four children. For the sake of their future, she and her husband help each other to earn an income and to support their children's studies.

Judith's husband is a carpenter in their village. He also cultivates their farm during the planting season while Judith sells fish in the village. She acquires her products from Dagupan City and sells them via house to house delivery. Her average daily income is 350 PHP, which she uses to provide for their daily needs and the children's schooling. Since their children are now at college level, the couple need to earn more income to support and finance the children's tuition fees and allowances. Judith wants to improve her small business but she has only a small amount of capital. Therefore, she wants to borrow 5,000 PHP, which she will put with her own capital to acquire more fish to sell in the village. She hopes that this will be a great help to her in improving her small business.

loans.use: As additional capital to purchase more fish

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en:
J. Chinbat is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Harhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son and two daughters attend a local secondary school.

Chinbat operates a raw material trading business in his town. He sells animal skins, primarily sheep and goat skins. He started his business in 1999 after previously working as a driver for a state-owned farm. Over the years, Chinbat has become quite experienced in raw materials trading and has built a stable operation. He is now planning to expand his business in the near future. Chinbat's business is very important to him and his family. He says, "All I want is to provide for my children's education and raise them to be good people." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase sheep and goat skins to sell for his business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: F. Pauline est née le 26 Janvier 1975 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Pauline est mariée à TOBOSSI Célestin, un maçon, et est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble depuis neuf ans au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou. Pauline assure avec son mari les charges de la famille. Pauline a très tôt abandonné l’école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins, Pauline vend des glacières, des bols en séries, plastiques, de l’huile végétale et également des tissus par le système de distribution. Pauline  s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pauline mène cette activité depuis sept ans. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Pauline sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer davantage son activité et la diversifier également par la vente de sacs pour dames.
texts.en:
F. Pauline was born on January 26, 1975 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to TOBOSSI Célestin, a mason, and is the mother of four children who are all in school.  The family has been living in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou for nine years.  Pauline ensures along with her husband that family expenses are met.  Early on, Pauline dropped out of school.  To support herself, she sells insulated containers, nested bowls, plastic ware, vegetable oil, and also cloth through the distribution system.  She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has been in this business for seven years.  Pauline is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé to bolster her business more and to diversify it as well, through the sale of women's bags. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy coolers, nested bowls, bolts of cloth, and bags

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminia E. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 49 years old. Herminia is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Herminia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Herminia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP average a month for these activities.

In 2008, Herminia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Herminia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Herminia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield and fertilizers like manure. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Herminia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield and fertilizers like manure

loans.name: Junica's Group

texts.en:
“A man without determination will not succeed!” says Mrs. Junica B., the loving wife of Rambert Theodore B. of barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with two children namely, Rafael Jean Andrei and Jhobeyl Quinz Xavier B.. They want their children to be successful in their chosen profession so that they will have a stable job someday.

Junica's husband's occupation is that of nurse employed by the PLTCI LAT Medical Center located at Bascaran, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya while Junica is engaged in selling AVON, Natasha and MSE products in their village to earn additional income. Being friendly and approachable, she acquires many customers who order her products. In this regard, she wants to acquire more products but she has inadequate capital. Therefore, she applied for loan to the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP8,000 to strengthen her capital and acquire more products to be sold in their village.

loans.use: additional capital for her costmetics-sales business

loans.name: Salami

texts.en: Salami sells computer accessories. He also photocopies documents for his customers. The demand for his services is high in his community. He has been in this business for a long time. He is married with 4 children and he is 47 years old. He hopes to own a computer centre in the future. He is requesting the loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase a photocopier and computer accessories. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a photocopier and computer accessories

loans.name: Rose

texts.fr: T. Rose est née le 23 Août 1974 et est mariée à LAWANI Rafiou, un frigoriste. Rose est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble depuis neuf ans au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rose supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Rose a été à l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Rose vend des produits divers (huile d’arachide, huile de palme, savons, omo, conserves, lait, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, riz, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rose fait ses achats. Rose mène cette activité depuis sept ans déjà et est à son quatrième crédit. C’est une cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de satisfaire la demande nombreuse de ses clients, Rose sollicite auprès de ALIDé un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
T. Rose was born on Auguest 23, 1974 and is married to LAWANI Rafiou, a refrigeration specialist.  She is the mother of two children who are both in school.  For nine years, the family has lived together in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Along with her husband, she provides for the family. Rose has attended secondary school.  To provide for herself, she sells a variety of goods (peanut oil, palm oil, soaps, Omo, canned foods, milk, pasta, sugar, rice, etc.) out of her home.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she makes her purchases.  Rose has been in this business for seven years already and is on her fourth loan.  She is an ALIDé client who repays her loans.  To increase her working capital and to satisfy the numerous demands of her customers, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of pasta, containers of peanut oil and palm oil, soaps, Omo, sacks of rice, and sugar

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en:
Abiola is 40 years old and married with two children. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Abiola sells foodstuffs and also has a grinding machine. With the profits from these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the needs of her family. She has been in business for a long time.
Abiola has been with Kiva partner LAPO for two years. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Togtokhbayar

texts.en:
C. Togtokhbayar lives with his wife and two daughters in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife is currently employed at the regional weather-forecasting and science center. His oldest daughter is 12 years old and attends a local secondary school and his youngest is in kindergarten. Togtokhbayar operates a raw material trading business in his town, dealing in animal skins, primarily sheep and goat skins. He started his business in 1999 with capital of 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). He has proven to be a successful businessman over the years and is well established in the local business community. Togtokhbayar manages his business by himself and works hard to increase his earnings. He says, "My main business objective is to supply quality products to my customers." He hopes his continued success will enable him to provide his children with a quality life. Togtokhbayar is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase sheep and goat skins to sell in his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Chultemdorj

texts.en:
H. Chultemdorj is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Govi-Altai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is a plumber, her eldest child currently serves in the Mongolian military, and her youngest child is a college student. 

Chultemdorj operates a small clothing production business in her town. She started her business in 2006 by renting a stall at a local trading center to sell her clothes. She has managed her business quite successfully over the years and plans to expand in the near future. She hopes to soon purchase more sophisticated sewing machines that will allow her to increase the quality of her products. Uranchimeg is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase fabrics and materials to make new clothes for her business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

 To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

 To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials to make new clothes

loans.name: Teriya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Teriya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 40 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de fruits et des habits. Les habillements sont achetés à Bamako, les fruits sont achetés sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elles vendent sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 49 900FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Teriya group are married women with an average age of 40 and 4 children. With their husband and children they live in large traditional families in the town of Dioïla in the prefecture of Dioïla, which lies in the region of Koulikoro in the Republic of Mali. They got to know each other through neighbours and relatives. They trade various products. These women have joined the microfinance company Soro Yiriwaso with the aim of sustaining their profitable business. They are on their tenth group loan and all their previous loans have been repaid punctually. With this new loan they are planning to buy a large quantity of fruit and clothes. They buy the clothes in Barnako and the fruits both locally and in surrounding villages. They sell locally in Dioïla to both male and female customers. They estimate that they will make a monthly profit of 49,900FCFA per person. A part of the profits is reinvested in the business while part is used for the family's daily expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and fruit

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 55 years old and married with seven children, all of whom are excelling in school.
Funke makes and sells yam flour, popularly known as “elubo” in Nigeria. “Elubo” is used in the preparation of “amala" (a yam paste or porridge). She has been in this business for a long time. Funke is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yam to make more yam flour to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association Bolodignogoma sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 5 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le  commerce d’articles divers. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe et tous les trois prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de charbon de bois et  des savons. Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place et dans les villages environnants et sont revendus sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  Elles envisagent  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group of the Bolodignogoma association are married women with an average age of 36 and 5 children . They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the city of Dioïla, located in the Dioïla prefecture of the Koulikoro region in Mali.

They know each other through their ties of community and kinship. These women sell various items, and they have incorporated the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to sustain their lucrative business. They are in their fourth group loan and all three previous loans have been properly reimbursed.

With this loan they plan to buy a large quantity of charcoal and soaps. They supply themselves locally and from surrounding villages, reselling on site in Dioïla to a clientele of women and men. They plan to make a monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA per person. The profits are partly reinvested in their business, with the rest going towards daily family expenses.


Translated from French by Jarred Taylor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal and soaps

loans.name: Obéissance Plus Group

texts.fr:
Tshibangu K. 50 ans, est dirigeant d’un groupe des micro-entrepreneurs dénommé « Obéissance Plus». Il est composé de 33 membres solidaires qui ont besoin des microcrédits de la part des prêteurs du monde à travers Kiva et l’IMF HOPE RDC dans le but de développer leurs affaires. 
Tshibangu vend des bijoux et autres articles divers dans un marché situé au sud-ouest de la ville de Kinshasa. Il est micro entrepreneur depuis 1990 et a acquit une solide expérience dans ce domaine. Tshibangu est client fidèle qui a obtenu 5 fois les crédits chez l’IMF HOPE RDC et les a remboursés correctement. Actuellement, son activité lui génère un bénéfice de $150 par semaine. Il compte avec le prochain prêt acheter les bijoux et autres articles à revendre pour renforcer le capital. Son ambition est d’épargner beaucoup afin de faire face aux moments difficiles dans l’avenir. Tshibangu est marié et père de 3 enfants âgés de 12 à 17 ans. Tous vont à l’école.
texts.en:
Tshibangu K., aged 50, is the leader of a group of micro-entrepreneurs called "Obéissance Plus".  It is composed in solidarity of 33 members who have a need for micro-loans from the lenders of the world via Kiva and the micro-finance institution HOPE RDC.  The goal of the members is to develop their businesses.  Tshibangu sells jewelry and a variety of other items at a marketplace located southwest of the city of Kinshasa.  He has been a micro-entrepreneur since 1990 and has acquired solid experience in this domain.  He is a loyal client who has obtained a loan five times with HOPE RDC, and he has repaid them properly.  Right now, his business generates a profit of $150 for him per week.  He intends to use the next loan to buy jewelry and other goods to sell in order to bolster his capital.  His ambition is to save a lot of money for coping with hard times in the future.  He is married and the father of three children, ages 12 to 17 years.  They all go to school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry and a variety of items to sell for bolstering his capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Djekadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 37 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers pour aider leur mari. 
Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont  à leur premier  prêt solidaire et comptent l’utiliser pour acheter, une grande quantité de fruits et légumes et  divers articles de commerce. Les articles divers sont achetés à Bamako, quant aux fruits et légumes ils sont achetés sur place et dans les villages environnants. 
Elles font leurs ventes, en détail au comptant et à crédit, sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 49 900FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djekadi are married women averaging 37 years of age and 4 children each.  With their husband and children, they live in large traditional families and reside in the city of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali. The women know one another by ties of community and kinship.  They do commerce in a variety of goods to help their husband. These women joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of preserving their lucrative businesses.  They are on their first solidarity loan and intend to use it to buy a large quantity of fruit and vegetables and various commercial goods.  The various goods are bought in Bamako.  As for the fruit and vegetables, these are bought locally and in surrounding villages.  Sales are made retail in cash or on credit, locally in Dioïla, to customers composed of women and men.   The group members envision realizing a monthly profit of 49,900 francs CFA per person.  A portion of the profits will be reinvested into business, and the other portion will be used to cover day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Yomi

texts.en:
Yomi is 24 years old and single without children, but she hopes to get married very soon. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Yomi is a very hardworking woman who works long hours to ensure that there is food on the table to feed her elderly parents.
Yomi makes yam flour and sells it at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. She hopes to be a distributor of yam flour in her community. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yam to make more yam flour to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to make yam flour

loans.name: Rosemarilyn

texts.en:
Rosemarilyn B. is from the town of Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old, is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarilyn owns and operates a business venture in  agriculture sector. While not the only means for generating revenue the means source of income comes primarily from raising pigs for sale in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Rosemarilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her piggery.

Rosemarilyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 


About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.en:
Mrs. Enriqueta V. is a resident of Barangay DTM, Regidor St. Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She and her husband have three children and, in order to give their children a better future, they help each other to finance the children's schooling. They endure hardships and difficulties to earn income for their daily needs and for their children's tuition fees and allowances.
Enriqueta's husband is a jeepney driver while Enriqueta makes handicrafts for Christmas. She makes her products to order. In addition to her handicraft business, she also sells peanut butter. Her average monthly income is 6,000 PHP, which is used to meet their daily needs and finance their children's schooling.
Enriqueta wants to improve her business so she can earn more income. Since her capital is insufficient, she wants to borrow 7,000 PHP from KIVA lenders. She hopes that this will be a great help to her in improving her small business.

loans.use: As additional capital to improve her handicrafts business

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en: Mrs. Rorn C. lives in the Ta Rab Doun Sar village in Kandal province. She is 67 years old and stays at home. She is a widow with five children; two are employed in a garment factory, another is a motorbike taxi driver, and the others are fruit and vegetable sellers in the local market. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it by purchasing more lotuses to resell to earn more income. Thus, Mrs. Rorn C. is asking for a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: Purchasing more lotuses to resell to earn more income

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association  Benkadi Wolemekin sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 27 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers pour aider leur mari. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de fruits et légumes et  bien d’autres articles divers. Les articles divers sont achetés à Bamako, les fruits et légumes sont achetés sur place et dans les villages environnants et sont revendus sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles comptent  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group, part of the Benkadi Wolemekin association, are married women. Their average age is 27, and they have three children each on average. With their husbands and children, they belong to large traditional extended families. They live in the town of Diolla in the Koulikoro region of the Republic of Mali.
