To help out their husband, they trade in a variety of items. They are known for their ties to their families and their neighbors. They belong to Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, in order to put their business on a firmer future footing. Currently, they are on their second group loan. The first one was paid back with no problems. With the next loan, they plan to buy fruit and vegetables in bulk in nearby villages and to buy other miscellaneous items in Bamako. Everything will be sold in Dioïla. Their customers are both women and men. They hope that they will each make 25,000 CFA a month. Part of their earnings will be reinvested in the business, and the rest will pay day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various products

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita J. is from the village of Sto. Niño. She is 47 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Lolita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2006, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used as additional working capital and to purchase construction materials for house improvement. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital and to purchase construction materials for house improvement

loans.name: Nyamjav

texts.en:
Nyamjav is 54 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His daughter, 20, attends university and his two sons, 11 and 10, both attend a local secondary school. Nyamjav makes and sells wooden products in his town. He began his business in 1989 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD). As he reaches his 20th year in business, his working capital now exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). He has gained not only business experience during his 20 years in service, but he has also gained more advanced carpentry skills. Nyamjav’s customers know that he makes quality, beautiful products and they know that he is a trustworthy, conscientious business owner. He says, “I want to expand my business and be able to afford my children’s education.” He is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more wood for his business so that he can keep growing his business in the future. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for his business

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch S. lives in the Pour Ta Mouk village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder and sells the duck eggs. Her poultry business is going well, so she wants to expand it by purchasing 100 more ducks for breeding and duck food. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions.

Her husband, Mr. Im Phorn, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. This couple has four children; one is a teacher in the local school, two others are farmers, and the other child attends the local school.

loans.use: Purchase 100 more ducks for breeding and duck food

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djiguissèmè sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 37 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce  d’articles divers pour aider leur mari. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont leur premier prêt de groupe avec l’institution. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de fruits et légumes et  beaucoup d’articles divers. Les articles divers sont achetés à Bamako et les fruits et légumes sont achetés sur place et dans les villages  environnants. Elles vendent  sur place à Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 49 900FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Djiguissèmè Group are married women, with an average age of 37 and 4 children. They live together with their husbands and their children in large traditional families in the city of Dioïla, District of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali. They met each other through family and neighborhood connections. To help their husbands, they have a retail business and sell various products. These women have joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, hoping to improve their business. With this first loan, they intend to buy a considerable amount of fruits and vegetables, as well as several other products. They buy all these different items in Bamako, while fruits and vegetables come from their own neighborhood. Their customers are men and women of their hometown, Dioïla.

They aim to achieve an individual monthly profit of 49 900FCFA. Part of this profit will be invested in their business, the rest will be used to provide for the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables and other products

loans.name: Georgina Kalekye

texts.en:
Georgina is married to Fredrick and they have one child, Faith, who is two years old.

Georgina was introduced to KADET though existing clients and she has no previous credit history. She has been operating a general store for nine years and she has applied for a loan that she intends to use to increase her stock of sugar, oil, soap, rice and paraffin among other goods.

Georgina's business is in a highly populated area and her clients are mainly the residents of the area. With the extra profits, she intends to open a mini-supermarket as her hopes are to eventually open a big supermarket. She describes herself as hardworking and focused to face challenges head-on.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase her stock of goods like sugar, oil, and soap

loans.name: Firas

texts.en:
Firas is a 28-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Firas has owned a barber shop since 2002. Firas requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to change the décor of his shop. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.

Firas is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and does good work. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all the needed tools for his shop. Firas decided to go into this business because he wanted to have independent work; in addition, he learned the skills in an academy. In the future, he plans on improving his business by purchasing more sophisticated tools.

loans.use: To change the décor of his shop

loans.name: Taofeek

texts.en: Taofeek is a happily married man. He has 2 children and he is 27 years old.  He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He sells drinks and local gin at retail prices to his customers. His greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. This is the high season for his business and he hopes to meet the demands of his customers. Taofeek is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and local gin to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and local gin to sell

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap P. is a villager in Prey Mei Lang Thboung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Nhanh Touch, is a construction worker.

Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support their family. In order to improve the family, Mrs. Sopheap P. decided to ask for a loan to buy coffee, glasses, plates, and ingredients to make snacks to sell; she will use the rest of money to buy a battery for bright light. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy coffee, glasses, plates, and ingredients to make snacks to sell

loans.name: Minata

texts.fr:
Madame   Minata  C.  est âgée de 47 ans, veuve et mère  de 4 enfants.  Elle  vit avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au 2ème quartier de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales, car à cette époque (pendant son enfance) l’enseignement des filles n’était pas une priorité pour les parents. Elle  s’initie très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce de poissons, appris auprès d’une de ses amies d’enfance. Après une année d’apprentissage (comment frire et enlever les parties non consommables), elle évolue seule depuis maintenant 29 ans et  jouit d’une grande  notoriété et connue de tout Ségou. Elle a comme clients les agents des administrations publiques (Douanes, Tribunal, Mairie etc.) 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son 1er prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 75Kg de poissons frais. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et effectue sa    vente au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de satisfaire ses propres besoins (nourriture, habillement, médicaments) et de payer les charges scolaires de ses enfants. 
Son ambition est de construire son terrain nu en  maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Minata C., 47, is a widow and the mother of 4 children. She lives with her co-spouse and their children in a big extended traditional family in the second district of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She did not attend school for socio-economic reasons, since at that time (during her childhood) educating daughters was not a priority for parents. She began earning money at an early age, especially selling fish, learning the business from one of her childhood friends. After a year's apprenticeship (learning how to fry fish and remove the parts that can't be eaten) she began working by herself. She has been at it now for 29 years and has a good reputation and is known in all of Ségou. Among her customers are civil servants (from Customs, the Court, the Town Hall, etc.)

Wishing to grow her working capital so as to make more profit, she came to Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first individual loan which she intends to use to buy 75 kg of fresh fish. She buys it right where she works and sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of women and men.

With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 50,000 F CFA. This profit will allow her to support herself (food, clothing, medicines) and pay the school fees for her children. Her ambition is to use her vacant lot to build a family home.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pour acheter des poissons.

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
Moustafa is a 42-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Moustafa has been working as a school bus driver since 1996. Moustafa requested this loan from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his bus and to purchase a car for his wife. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.
Moustafa is special in his work because he is punctual and  trustworthy. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Moustafa decided on doing this business because he wanted to improve his income.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his bus and purchase a car for his wife.

loans.name: Ngumbi

texts.en:
Ngumbi M. is a married father of six living in Bamenda, Cameroon.

Ngumbi M. is a passionate individual who has been working with GHAPE since 2005. To date, Ngumbi has accepted three loans and has successfully repaid his debt in all three instances. He has also faithfully supported his lending group when needed.

Having recently experienced the passing of both his father and mother, Ngumbi has had some significant unexpected expenses. His livestock have been a necessary source of income in order to provide for his family. Ngumbi is currently requesting a small loan to assist with the purchase of pigs, chickens and feed for each. He is also familiar with the necessary medications required to keep livestock healthy. Part of his loan would be put towards ensuring his livestock remain in good health. Ngumbi considers that he will continue to do very well in the sales of livestock because he has several loyal customers and significant experience in the raising of animals.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase livestock, feed and animal medications

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey P. lives in Phnhos village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder who sells duck eggs in the local market. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing 1000 ducklings for breeding, and duck food.

Mrs. Srey P. is 42 years old and the mother of five children; one is a cow middleman and the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Sokha, is a farmer who owns 5-hectar field of land to cultivate rice.

loans.use: To purchase 1000 ducklings for breeding, and duck food

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nayfa

texts.en:
Nayfa is a 35-year-old woman who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with her husband and their four children. Nayfa has owned a grocery store since 2006. She also sells candies, canned food, and other items. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Nayfa has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.
Nayfa is special in her work because she offers a wide range of products. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and traders. When she first started this business, she didn’t have enough cash. Nayfa decided on doing her business because she wanted to supplement her husband’s income. In the future, she plans on improving her store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Mireille Clarisse

texts.fr: G. Mireille Clarisse est née le 01 Décembre 1983 et est mariée à OUSSOUKPEVI Rodrigue, un commerçant. Le couple a un seul enfant qui est scolarisé. La famille vit ensemble au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou depuis bientôt neuf ans. Mireille Clarisse vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Mireille Clarisse a été à l’école jusqu’au secondaire. C’est depuis quatre ans que Mireille Clarisse vend des produits divers (riz, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, cigarettes, bonbons, biscuits, lait, savons, etc) et également des cartes de recharges téléphoniques à son domicile. Mireille Clarisse s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Mireille Clarisse sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter davantage le stock de produits et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
G. Mireille Clarisse was born on December 1, 1983 and is married to OUSSOUKPEVI Rodrigue, a merchant.  The couple has just one child who is in school.  The family has been living together for nine years in the Sènadé district in Cotonou.  She works in aid of her husband to provide for the family. Mireille Clarisse has attended class through secondary school.  For four years in her home, she has been selling a variety of goods (rice, canned foods, pasta, cigarettes, candy, cookies, milk, soaps, etc.) and also mobile phone recharge cards. She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the first time she's requesting a loan from ALIDé, so as to increase her inventory some more and to satisfy her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, boxes of milk and soaps, and pasta

loans.name: Munkhbat

texts.en:
Munkhbat is 23 years old and lives with his wife and 3-year-old son in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is a university student, his son goes to a local kindergarten, and Munkhbat operates a cell phone repair business. He began his business in 2003 in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. When he and his wife moved to Khovd in 2006, he brought his business with him. In the past six years, he has become very experienced in his business field and has managed to save enough of his business profits to purchase a car for his family. Munkhbat says, “My business is growing quite well, but in the future, I would like to sell phones as well as repair them.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase cell phone parts for his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase cell phone parts

loans.name: Nerm

texts.en: Mrs. Nerm V. is 54 years old and she lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 4-hectare rice field. Because this plantation is infertile and far from an irrigation system, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, a water pump, and gasoline to pump water to the field. Her husband, Mr. Kim Yorn, owns a mechanical and rice mill machine which have been hired by the villager. This couple has two children, one of whom is a farmer and the other a student. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, a water pump, and gasoline.

loans.name: Mach

texts.en: Mrs. Mach M. is a villager in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She breeds ducks for sale and her husband, Mr. Kaem Chhan, grows rice on a 2-hectare field. Mrs. Mach M. is requesting a loan to buy duck feed and fertilizer and to pay for plowing the rice field. She is 37 years old and the mother of four children, of whom one  is employed in a garment factory, two attend the local school, and the youngest is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and pay for plowing.

loans.name: Adam

texts.en: Adam V., 54, is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. He tills a 2-hectare rice field as the source of income for his family. He's a father of 2 children. The eldest is 24 years old. He needs additional capital to finance his farm. He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. He will use the loan to purchase farm supplies and improve his rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 44-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Mahmoud has been in the sanitation business since 1985. Mahmoud requested this loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase some tools and electricA. wires for his work. Mahmoud has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time.

Mahmoud is speciA. in his work because of his experience. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a big network, but after almost 25 years of experience, he has an extremely big network. Mahmoud decided on doing this business because he learned it when he was young. His plan for the future is to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase some tools and electrical wires for his work

loans.name: Oybarchin

texts.ru: Соатова Ойбарчин проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 35 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж находится в России на заработках. Сама Ойбарчин более 14 лет занимается выращиванием овощей и пшеницы. Она выращивает, одну часть продает, а другую оставляет для своего употребления. Кредит просит дял покупки семян и удобрений, чтобы посеить новый урожай.
texts.en:
Oybarchin S. lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 35 years old. She is married and has three children. Her husband is now working in Russia. Oybarchin herself has been growing vegetables and wheat for more than fourteen years. She sells a part and keeps the other part for consumption. She is asking for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer to sow a new harvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en:
Altangerel is 54 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His daughter, 23, attends university and his son, 17, attends a local secondary school. Altangerel operates a firewood retail business in his town. He began his business in 1990 with working capital of 700,000 tugrugs (about 490 USD) and a truck so that he could haul the firewood to his customers. In the 19 years since he began his business, he has managed to grow his working capital to exceed 1,500,000 tugrugs (about 1050 USD) and has a loyal customer base due to his belief in good customer service. Altangerel says, “Being nice to my customers has been the key to my business success.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more firewood to sell during the upcoming winter months.

About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Wafaa

texts.en:
Wafaa is a 55-year-old woman who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with her husband and their child. Wafaa has been operating a grocery store since 1998. She sells candies, chips, canned food, home cleaning products, and lots more. Wafaa requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. Wafaa has been a microcredit client for nine years now and has always paid on time.

Wafaa is special in her work because she is an active woman; she does three jobs at the same time in order to improve her family’s income. She has to take care of her grocery store, and she also has an olive plantation and works as a housekeeper. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties since she had saved money in order to open her store. In the future, she plans to keep improving her store and consequently her financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice A. owns a 1-hectare rice field. She’s 57 years old and has a rice farming business in Norala, South Cotabato. She started her business way back in 1982. With the income she receives from her farm, the financial problems in sustaining the needs of her family are met.

Alice joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a loan for her farm. She requested an amount of 15,000 Philippine pesos as additional capital to finance her business. With this amount, she can buy fertilizers, seeds, and other farm supplies.

loans.use: Fertilizers, seeds, and farm supplies

loans.name: Sylvie

texts.fr: H. Sylvie est née en 1974 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Sylvie est mariée à AHLONSOU Jacques et est mère de trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Sylvie vit avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Kpankpan à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis neuf ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Sylvie a très tôt abandonné l’école. Il y a six ans de cela que Sylvie mène comme activité, la vente de comprimés, des pâtes dentifrice et des brosses à dent à son domicile. Sylvie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Sylvie sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir son commerce.
texts.en:
H. Sylvie was born in 1974 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married to AHLONSOU Jacques and is the mother of three children, some of whom are in school.  She has been living with her husband and children for nine years in the Kpankpan district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  The couple provides for the family jointly  Very early on, Sylvie dropped out of school.  For six years, she has been selling pills, toothpaste, and toothbrushes out of her home.  She supplies herself from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé to augment her working capital and to expand her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tablets, toothpaste, and toothbrushes

loans.name: Asef

texts.en: Asef is a 29-year-old single man living alone. He has owned an aluminum manufacturing and assembly shop for the past two years and had 7 years of previous experience in the field. Today, Asef is requesting a $1,200 loan in order to purchase new inventory for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Yom Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Yom T. is the president of a village bank loan group that consists of 14 people from Sarei Sambath village in Kandal province.  She is farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She needs fertilizer and pesticide for her field because it is infertile. Thus, she decided use her share of this loan to buy these things to support her field. Mrs. Yom T. is a widow with a child who helps her on the farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia G. is from the village of Diwan. She is 55 years old. Patricia is widowed and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Patricia owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks in the local community. Patricia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Patricia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patricia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Patricia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Patricia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Ichinhorol

texts.en:
Ichinhorol is a 34-year-old divorced single mother who lives with her parents, younger sister and 5-year-old child in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. They all live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Ichinhorol operates a fruit and vegetable business in a stall at the local market. She began her business in 2008 with working capital of 150,000 tugrugs (about 105 USD) and in only one year, her working capital has more than doubled to exceed 300,000 tugrugs (about 210 USD). She is working hard so that she can save enough money to pay for her child’s school fees next year. She says, “I would like to expand my business in the future in order to improve my child’s quality of life.” Ichinhorol is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more fruit for her business.

About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit for her business

loans.name: Felly

texts.en:
Felly C., 47, is a rice farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She manages a 3-hectare rice field. She also has a hog raising business. Felly supports her family of four children; the eldest is 25 years old. She works hard in order to have a good harvest.

She is limited in her capital. That’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a loan. She’s requesting 8,000 Philippine pesos to support her business in buying seeds and farm materials.

loans.use: Seeds and farm materials

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 48-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Ahmad has been selling and producing home-made “mouneh,” which are agricultural products, since 1983. In Arabic, mouneh is food that is stored for later consumption, such as pickles, jams, tomato paste, and radishes. Ahmad requested this loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase some merchandise for his shop. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him improve his work by diversifying his merchandise and expanding his stock. Ahmad is special in his work because he sells products of good quality. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Ahmad decided on doing this business because he likes working in this kind of field. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase some merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Kisa Kya Mukama Group, Mityana

texts.en: B. Teddy is the leader of her lending group in Mityana. She is a hardworking and devoted lady with a poultry farm business that she has been running in Wabigalo for 1 year. She is also a teacher by profession, hence being able to have a double income every month. Since her poultry business is still small, she is able to get 20,000/= as profits and she hopes for this to increase. She keeps mostly egg laying chickens and she would like to begin raising broilers to expand her business. Teddy is a married woman with 3 children aged 5, 3 and 2 years and she takes care of 1 additional dependent. She is a friendly lady and she needs a loan to help buy more chickens for expansion.

loans.use: Buying more chickens for farm expansion

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel is a mother of four currently living in Asugkah, just outside of Bamenda.  

Through various struggles, Rachel has managed to keep a positive attitude that is reflected in her smile.  Rachel's most significant pain was the passing of her son.  She has also been dealing with being the sole provider for her family since her husband recently abandoned her and the children.  Despite her troubles, Rachel is very hopeful for her future and that of her children.   

Rachel has been a GHAPE member for 18 years!  She is currently on her ninth loan and has successfully repaid each one.  She has requested GHAPE for an additional loan in order to purchase socks and shoes to be sold at retail.  After an exploration into various businesses including the management of a farm and raising of livestock, Rachel believes her shoe and sock sales will not only succeed but be her best business to date because she can sell year round and there is little environmental risk.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of socks and shoes for resale

loans.name: Genoveva's Group

texts.en: Rice farming is the main source of income of Genoveva B., 54. She supports five children. Her 2-hectare rice field is just enough to provide for their basic needs. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a low-interest loan to finance her business. She’s requesting 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy necessities for the farm and sustain her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is unmarried and resides within Nairobi. Moses was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he has no credit history. He has been in the business of selling electrical appliances for eight years and he intends to use the loan to increase his stock of sockets, aerials and electric extension cords. He also sells greeting cards as a side business.

His business is located along a road and his clients are passers by. With the extra profits he plans to reinvest in the business and purchase more stock to open another outlet for selling electrical appliances.

Moses's future dream is to buy a plot of land and build rental houses. He describes himself as hardworking.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add stock (sockets, aerials, electric extension cords, etc.)

loans.name: Primov

texts.ru: Примов Ашур проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 48 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Ашур по специальности "бухгалтер". Он более 30 лет занимается сельским хозяйством, в основном выращивает овощи. Кредит просит для покупки семян, чтобы посеить новый урожай.
texts.en:
A. Primov lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 48 years old. He is married and has three children. A.'s profession is accounting. He has been in agriculture for more than 30 years and mainly grows vegetables. He is asking for a loan to buy seeds to sow a new harvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sow a new harvest

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en:
Rabih is a 30-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Rabih has been selling chickens since 2002. Rabih prices his chickens depending on their weights. Rabih requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase chickens for his work. This is the first time that Rabih has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

Rabih is special in his work because he sells "bio" chickens. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Rabih decided on doing this business because before he used to work as a car mechanic and he didn’t find a lot of work, so he decided on changing his work in order to improve his financial situation. He plans to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase chickens for his work

loans.name: Mrs. Sothea Seim Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sothea S. is the village bank president of a loan group that consists of 16 people in Chey Otdom village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sothea S. owns a shop to sell compact discs to the villagers. She now faces a small problem because most of her CDs do not work well. To improve the CDs, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy equipment to make CDs more smoothly.  She is a widow with two children who all attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy equipment to make CDs.

loans.name: Constantine

texts.fr: H. Constantine est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AHLONSOU Léopold un maçon, Constantine est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble depuis onze ans au quartier Midombo à Cotonou. Constantine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Ayant abandonné très tôt l’école, Constantine vend des tissus de façon ambulante à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est toujours à Dantokpa que Constantine s’approvisionne. Constantine a 8 ans d’expérience dans cette activité et est à son quatrième crédit à ALIDé. Constantine rembourse bien ses crédits à ALIDé. Constantine sollicite ce quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et augmenter la taille de sa marchandise pour satisfaire ses clients en cette période de préparation des fêtes de fin d’année.
texts.en:
H. Constantine was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to AHLONSOU Léopold, a mason, she is the mother of two children who are both in school.  The family has been living together for eleven years in the Midombo district in Cotonou.  Constantine helps her husband to meet family expenses.  Having dropped out of school early on, Constantine sells cloth from place to place at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Dantokpa is where she always stocks up.  She has eight years of experience in this business and is on her fourth loan with ALIDé.  She indeed repays her ALIDé loans.  She's requesting this fourth loan from ALIDé to bolster her working capital and to expand her offering of merchandise in preparation for the year-end holidays.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of fabrics

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen, 56, spends most of her time managing her rice farming business. She enjoys working on the farm because it provides for the food, shelter, and clothing of her family. Helen is married to Eddie and they have 3 children.

She would like to continue working on her farm for the sustenance of her family but she is limited in terms of financing for the business. That’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a loan intended for her business. She requested a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos, enough to buy materials and supplies she needs for the farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Jackline Nangami

texts.en:
Jackline K. is married to Lloyd and they have two children, Samuel and Zebedi. The client was introduced to KADET by existing clients, and has no previous credit history. She intends to use the loan to add stock of beauty products in the shop.

Her business is within a highly populated residential area. With the extra profit she anticipates to get, the client intends to re-stock her beauty shop.

Jackline hopes to own a cosmetic shop in future as she believes she is hard-working and sincere.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock in her salon

loans.name: Jennelyn

texts.en:
Jennelyn maintains a two and a half-hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. Though she doesn’t own the land, she was given the opportunity to manage a rice farming business. She is now 41 years old with 5 children to support. Her eldest is still only 17 years old. She tries hard so that she can send them to school and have them finish their studies.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 15,000 Php to purchase fertilizer and seeds for the farm.

loans.use: Fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Mrs. Goun Touch  Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people, all of whom live in Trabaek Pok village in Kandal province, comprise this particular village bank loan. The group members are seeking this loan for different business purposes, depending on the type of business they are engaged in.

Mrs. Goun T., for example, who was selected by her fellow members to be the village bank president, is a farmer. Indeed, she owns a small piece of land, on which she cultivates rice in order to earn a living. Aside from her farming operation, she also sews (and sells) thatched roofs to generate additional income. Because her business has been doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more raw materials for her roof-making business. Her husband, Mr. Yong Phalla, helps her with the businesses. Mrs. Goun T. has three children; one of her children is employed in a garment factory, another child is a construction worker, while the youngest child helps with the businesses.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more raw materials (in order to make, then sell, thatched roofs)

loans.name: Damir

texts.en:
M. Damir is 28 years old. He is married with 4 kids. Damir is a market vendor. He sells men’s clothes and shoes at the central market of Shahrituz. Over 5 years of working at the market, Damir already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has customers who always come to him. He is trying to satisfy the needs of any customers with various tastes and income levels.

Damir’s kids are small now but already today he is working hard in order to give them a good education and to make them happy. Today Damir is planning to increase his working capital in order to purchase new goods to sell. With this purpose he requests a loan of 2500 USD. He promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all supporting him. Your generosity can change their lives. Be an important part of the growth of Damir’s business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to sell

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito, 44, is living in Norala, South Cotabato and has a rice farming business. Being single, he devotes his time to working in his 2-hectare rice field. He heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. that offers financial support to entrepreneurs like him, and he later joined in June 2008.

His business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php. This amount will be helpful to sustain his business with a low interest charge.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 49 years old, married to Beatrice N., and they have three school-going children. He operates his butcher shop in Naivasha town and has done so for four years now.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan well.  He plans to restock his butchery with more beef, as he has only been dealing with goat meat. This will help him serve other clients who prefer beef over goat meat.

His future hopes are to buy a vehicle which he will use as a taxi offering transport to various destinations.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy beef to sell

loans.name: Zouheir

texts.en: Zouheir is a 26-year-old single man living with his parents and five siblings, three of whom are unemployed. At the age of 18, Zouheir’s father taught him how to make chicken sandwiches in his shop. In 2006, he took over his father’s store so that his father could retire and rest at home. Today, Zouheir is asking to borrow $1,200 in order to purchase new appliances for the business.

loans.use: to purchase new appliances

loans.name: Kim Chharn

texts.en:
Mr. Kim Chharn R. is a villager who lives in Srae Ampil village in Kandal province. He is a married man, and he and his wife (who is pictured with him in the photograph) have six children. Three of his children collect recyclables, while his other children attend the local school.

To earn a living, he is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows vegetables. Unfortunately, he is facing a problem with his business because his field has a lot of insects. Thus, Mr. Kim Chharn R. decided to ask for a loan to buy pesticides. Accordingly, with the loan proceeds, he expects to have a more productive growing season, with many more vegetables.

loans.use: To improve his farming operation by purchasing pesticides

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz P.'s rice-farming business is improving with the financial help offered by micro-finance institutions.  Since 2008 Luz has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI and one of Kiva's field partners.  She was able to finance her business with a small interest charge.

Now she is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to continually support her rice field.  She is glad that her daily needs are met by the income she makes.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ramazon

texts.en:
M. Ramazon is a married man with five children. His children are the reason that he tries so hard to provide them with a stable family life and an education for their future. For the past two years Ramazon has sold rice. This is a profitable business in his neighborhood, and his sales have increased considerably year after year. His start-up capital was from the severance pay he received from where he used to work. 

To expand his business, Ramazon is requesting a loan of $3000, which he intends to use for increasing the size of his inventory. The loan will greatly improve Ramazon’s income and his family's standard of living. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase more rice to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia S., age 59, is a rice farmer. She started her business way back in June 2008.  She is now managing a 3-hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato.  She loves her work on the farm.  Lydia is the mother of three children.  She strives hard in order to provide the basic needs of her family.

She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP from one of Kiva's field partners, Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to support in financing her farm.  With this amount, she will be able to buy seeds and farm supplies.

loans.use: Seeds and farm supplies

loans.name: Tété Jeanne

texts.fr: G. Tété Jeanne est née le 13 Janvier 1981 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Tété Jeanne est mariée et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Tété Jeanne vit seule avec ses enfants au quartier Midombo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est depuis 8 ans que Tété Jeanne est dans ce quartier. Tété Jeanne supporte seule les charges de la famille. Tété Jeanne a arrêté très tôt l’école et a appris le métier de coiffure. En plus de ce métier, Tété Jeanne vend des mèches, des produits pour cheveux et des cartes de recharges dans son atelier de coiffure sise à Midombo. C’est depuis 6 ans que Tété Jeanne exerce cette activité. Tété Jeanne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. C’est pour accroître la taille de son activité et augmenter sa clientèle que Tété Jeanne sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Tété Jeanne was born on January 13, 1981 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married and the mother of two children who are both in school.  She lives alone with her children in the Midombo district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She has been living in this district for eight years.  She alone provides for the family.  Very early on, Tété Jeanne stopped attending school and learned the trade of hairstyling.  In addition to this trade, she sells hair extensions, hair products, and mobile phone recharge cards in her salon near Midombo.  She has been in this business for six years.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  To grow her business and to increase her customer base, she's requesting a sixth loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and hairstyling products

loans.name: Minviluz

texts.en:
Minviluz is a rice farmer in Norala, South Cotabato. She is 53 years old with eight children and is able to sustain her family through her farm.

Minviluz manages a rice field that is three hectares (7.5 acres) in size. Now she needs financial assistance and that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan with a low interest rate. She has requested 15,000 Php to improve her farm and to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Hudjamurodov

texts.ru: Худжамуродаов Хасан проживает в районе Щахритуз. Возраст 54 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Сын работает на стройке. Жена помогает мужу. Сам Хасан более 4 лет занимается животноводством, он откармливает и продает крупно рогатый скот. Кредит просит для покупки скота.
texts.en:
H. Hudjamurodov lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 54 years old, he is married and has five children. His son works in construction. His wife helps her husband. H. has been doing animal husbandry for more than four years. He feeds and sells large cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Nazrullo

texts.en: Nazrullo is married and has six children but only three live with him. These three children are still in school and help him with his store. Nazrullo has thirteen years experience with his business selling groceries. With his small savings and on his own initiative, he decided to set up the store nine years ago. He thought about it because there wasn’t this type of business in his neighborhood. Thanks to the store, Nazrullo was able to buy a small used car which he uses to do deliveries in the mornings from time to time. His wife doesn’t work and when Nazrullo needs to go out she is in charge of selling the groceries. Nazrullo works everyday of the week from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. This hardworking father is motivated by his great love for his family. This is the third time Nazrullo has requested a loan from IMON International and he has proven to be responsible with his repayments in the past. He wants to use the loan to invest in his store. He is sincerely grateful for your support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to increase his range of goods

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao E. is a married woman who lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sein Sammuth, do not have children.

To earn a living, she is a farmer. Indeed, she and her husband, who helps her with the farming, own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. However, they have insufficient capital to buy fertilizer and an irrigation systE. (to support the field during the dry season). Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and a water machine in order to address these issues.

loans.use: To improve the business by purchasing fertilizers and an irrigation machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Seeds and farm supplies

loans.name: Raïmath

texts.fr: L. Raïmath est née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Raïmath est mariée à ADOGBO-MEDAGBE Armand, un commerçant. Le couple a un enfant qui n’est pas encore scolarisé. Raïmath vit avec son mari et son enfant au quartier Aïbatin à Cotonou, depuis deux ans. Raïmath assure les dépenses de la famille avec son mari. Raïmath a très tôt abandonné l’école et a appris le métier de coiffure. A côté de cela, Raïmath vend des mèches et des produits pour cheveux dans son salon de coiffure situé à Agbodjèdo à Cotonou. Raïmath a déjà 8 ans d’expérience dans ce métier. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Raïmath s’approvisionne. Raïmath est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, et a un comportement irréprochable dans les remboursements du crédit. Raïmath sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d’agrandir davantage la taille de son activité et de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
L. Raïmath was born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to ADOGBO-MEDAGBE Armand, a merchant.  The couple has one child who is not yet in school.  She has been living with her husband and child in the Aïbatin district in Cotonou for two years.  Along with her husband, she ensures that family expenses are met.  Early on, Raïmath dropped out of school and learned the trade of hairdressing.  Aside from this, she sells hair extensions and hair products in her hairstyling salon located in Agbodjèdo in Cotonou. She already has eight years of experience in this trade.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and from Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  Raïmath is a previous ALIDé client who has a spotless loan repayment record.  She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and hairstyling products

loans.name: Janerose

texts.en:
Janerose is 41 years old, married to Richard W., and they have five children who all attend school. She first heard about KADET during an awareness campaign organised by the company in Naivasha town.

She has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for the last 10 years and she has applied for this loan from KADET so that she can start an Mpesa service business within her clothes shop. Mpesa is the popular money transfer service from a local mobile service provider safaricom. With Mpesa people can send small amounts to other people through their mobile phones. For her to start offering the service, she is required to deposit a certain amount of money with the mobile phone company provider and this is where proceeds from this loan will go.

She also wants to increase her business of selling clothes, so that she can have a larger shop in the future.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To start an Mpesa (mobile money transfer) service as a side business.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of income for Rosana, 37. Her business is located in Norala, South Cotabato. She has a good harvest when the weather is good and no pests attack. She tills a 1-hectare rice field to support her family. She is a mother of 3 children, the eldest of whom is 12 years old.

She has requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 10,000 Php to provide additional capital for her business.

loans.use: Additional for rice farming business.

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz is 22 years old. He’s not married but runs his own business in order to support his parents with the family's expenses. He sells children’s clothes at the local market. Parviz is very enterprising, has vast experience working as a vendor, and is full of creative ideas. A reasonable pricing policy and client-friendly service have always been priorities in his work and have helped to ensure the success of his business. Parviz has been running his business for 5 years. He is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni ($700 USD) to increase his inventory. He believes that having this additional turnover capital will help him minimize his sales risk and provide stable financial support for his family. Moreover, it will help him get closer to his ultimate goal of purchasing a big store of his own one day.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new goods for sales.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mr. Thorn T. is a villager who lives in Tralach village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Nhoan Noem, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice.  In this plantation, they face a problem because the field is infertile which it is bad enough to affect their crop. Thus, Mr. Thorn T. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field. He would use the rest of the loan to buy more pesticides to make her crop more productive.

He is the father of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown on the picture with him.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for the rice field

loans.name: Badarch

texts.en:
Badarch T. is 51 years old and lives with his three sons in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest son is 25 years old and has finished school. His two youngest sons are both students. Byambadavaa, age 20, attends university and Janchivdorj, age 10, is in secondary school. Tsanjiid operates a mobile clothing trade business in his town. He travels to Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia, twice a month to purchase clothing products. He then goes door-to-door to local businesses and homes to sell his products. 

Tsanjiid started his business in 2009 and has quickly found success. He works very hard to understand his new business and has already gained much experience. He knows he must continue to work hard and improve his selling skills if he wants to improve his business. He says, "In the future, I hope to expand my business so that I can have one location to sell my clothes." However, today, Tsanjiid hopes to purchase a car which would allow him to expand his customer base and sell clothes more efficiently. Tsanjiid is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a car for his mobile clothing trade business.										

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.use: To purchase a car for his mobile clothing trade business.

loans.name: Mouna

texts.en: Mouna is a 20 year old single woman living with her parents and 3 siblings. In 2008, she started her own home-based beauty salon to help with the household expenses. Today, Mouna is requesting $1,200 in order to purchase new machines for the salon.

loans.use: To purchase new machines.

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru: Фотима Соатова проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 47 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Муж находится в России на заработках. Дети помогают матери по бизнесу. Фотима более 8 лет занимается торговлей сухофруктов. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Fotima S. lives close to Shahrituz, Tajikistan. She is forty-seven and married with five children. Her husband works in Russia. Her children help her with her business. Fotima has been selling dried fruits for over eight years. She is asking for a loan to increase her sales.


Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
Armine M. lives in Yerevan with her retired parents, brother and sister. Armine was a presenter on radio and TV, where she organized programs about a children's home named “Zatik” (“Ladybird”) in order to attract sponsors for it. After that, she, together with her brother, founded “Hope and Law” Christian Public Organization of Right Defence. Under this organization Armine has a publishing house, “Children’s world”, and all her employees are young people who have left the children’s home once they had grown up. They publish “My and your planet”, which is a colored children’s monthly newspaper, with a circulation of 4,000 copies in 3 languages: Armenian, English and Russian.

In May, 2009, after a street accident, Armine broke her leg. She can't walk, so she uses a wheelchair to do her duties, in order to realize a big number of programs for the children’s home and for children's education at Armenian University and Institutes when they have grown up.
 
Armine needs 600.000 AMD to publish books for children, which are translated by herself into Armenian and Russian from English. In the future, Armine hopes to engage a lot of people and organizations in her programs and establish connections with children's homes in other countries.

loans.use: To publish books for children.

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Mr. Socheat M. is a villager who lives in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. His wife, Mrs. Neang Khorn, is a garment factory worker who makes a small salary to support the family.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less money than needed to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mr. Socheat M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and he hopes to improve their standard of living with this loan.

Mr. Socheat M. is a father with two children who are both enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Bibirajab

texts.en: J. Bibirajab is the married mother of one adult son. She runs a small business selling men’s shoes and clothes in the local market and has been involved in this trade for eighteen years. Bibirajab recently moved her vending facility to a different location which has promoted an increase in her sales. Bibirajab has many loyal customers. She is very friendly and amiable with each client, thus giving her a unique talent in attracting new customers. Bibirajab purchases clothing wholesale every week. She is hoping to use the loan of 1,500 USD to purchase winter clothes and shoes for men. She hopes to see her venture grow big enough to afford to buy a new vending facility in the future. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.
