Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes and shoes for men

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mrs. Yim M., a villager who lives in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo Province, owns a small piece of land upon which she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Nob Reourn, uses a motorbike to pull a cart to transport passengers and goods for an income. Because his cart is now old and unreliable, Yim is requesting a loan to buy a new one for him.

They are the parents of five children, one of whom is a construction worker while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cart for her husband.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia C. is a 25 year old married lady with one daughter. Her husband is called Nicholas Kilonzo, and they reside in Bamburi, Mombasa. 
Lydia is a business lady and she sells a variety of ladies' shoes in the busy Kongowea market in Mombasa. She has been in this business for the last two years and her business has been quite a success. She has been able to grow from one shoe stall to four stalls in the span of two years.

Lydia was introduced to KADET by a client and is currently accessing her first loan. She plans to purchase more ladies' shoes to give her clients an even broader variety to choose from. Through subsequent KADET loans Lydia hopes to venture into other major Kenyan towns and to also start selling ladies' clothes. 


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase ladies' shoes.

loans.name: Francine

texts.fr: A. Francine est née en 1974 à Sakété, dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Francine est mariée à MONNOU Augustin, un mécanicien. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C'est depuis sept ans que Francine réside au quartier Djédjélayé à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin), avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Francine a très tôt abandonné l'école. Depuis neuf ans, Francine vend des pièces détachées à son domicile. A côté de cela, Francine vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs rouge, riz, accompagné de sauce). C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Francine s'approvisionne. Francine est à son 5ème crédit et rembourse bien ses crédits. Francine sollicite ce 5ème crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
A. Francine was born in 1974 in Sakété, not far from Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married to MONNOU Augustin, a mechanic.  The couple has two children who are both in school.  For seven years, she has been residing in the Djédjélayé district in Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin) with her husband and children.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  Very early on, Francine dropped out of school.  For nine years, she has been selling spare parts out of her home.  Aside from this, she sells food (red cornmeal mash, rice).  She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Francine is on her fifth loan, and she indeed repays her loans.  She's requesting this fifth loan from ALIDé to augment her working capital and to expand her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs, de riz et des condiments de sauce

loans.name: Samorn

texts.en: Mrs. Samorn M. is a villager who lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She is farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In their plantation, she has a problem because their field is infertile. Thus, Mrs. Samorn M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She would use the rest of the loan to pay her child's school fees. Her husband, Mr. Vong Vuthy, is a soldier who has a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Samorn M. is a mother of one child who is studying in VCDs repairer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive

loans.name: Narzieva

texts.en:
Narzieva D. operates a small business selling men’s clothes. She has an attractively arranged store at Penjikent market in Tajikistan, where she carries all sorts of necessary clothes. Narzieva has been in business for about 6 years and has developed a stable, profitable enterprise based on products that are always in demand. Her business has become the main source of income for her family. Her business is growing, and she has requested a loan of 4500 Somoni to increase her working capital and help boost the further development of her business. With your help this will be possible.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing to sell.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en: Mrs. Vanny S. is a villager who lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Eom Chamroeun, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice.  In this plantation, they face a problem because the field is infertile which has a bad to effect on their crop. Thus, Mrs. Vanny S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. This couple does not have any children. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 22 year old single man. He has been working as a taxi driver since 2006 to provide, along with his brothers, better living conditions for the family. Today, Hassan is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy the rented car he has been driving to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy the rented car he has been driving for his taxi business.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Hoeurn C. is a villager who lives in Phngeas village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectare field of land to cultivate rice on. Her husband, Mr. Dak Pros, is a duck breeder. Since this poultry business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Hoeurn C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks and duck food for their poultry business. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Hoeurn C. has three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school. The other is too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy more ducks and duck food for their poultry business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sarantungalag

texts.en:
B. Sarantungalag is 44 years old and lives with her son in an apartment in the Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her son is 17 years old and attends the local high school. Sarantungalag operates a garment making business out of a rented stall at a small trading center in her town. She both designs and produces all of the clothes herself. She travels to the capital city of her province 2 to 3 times a month to purchase new materials for her business. Sarantungalag previously worked as a dressmaker for a different clothing business. During this time she gained much experience and skill in her trade. Today, her business is well known throughout her community and her customers like her business because she can produce clothing specific to their needs. Sarantungalag works hard to grow her business and provide quality clothes to her customers. Her business is very important to her as it is the only source of income for her and her son. She says, "All I want is to be able to provide for my son's education so that he will become a successful person." Sarantungalag is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~420 USD) loan to pay her son's tuition fees.



About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: to pay her son's tuition fees

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en: K. is married and the father of 2 young children. He has owned a car painting shop since 2000. Their is great demand for his services, which is why he is requesting a loan of $1,100 to buy more merchandise for his clients.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise

loans.name: Dilovar

texts.en: A. Dilovar is 42 years old. She is an experienced businesswoman and a loving mother to three children. She has her own sewing machine and runs her business from her home. Dilovar is a well-known seamstress in her community, since she has been working there for more than three years. Through word of mouth, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. Now she is requesting a loan of $1500 USD to purchase a new sewing machine and fabrics for sewing traditional dresses. This will help improve the quality of life of her family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the new sewing machine and fabrics for sewing the national dresses.

loans.name: Nurinisso

texts.ru: Кароматова Нуриниссо проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст 37 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж занимается организацией свадеб, и их ведением. Сама же клиентка более 5 лет занимается выращиванием овощей и их продажей. Кредит просит для закупа семян и удобрений.
texts.en:
Nurinisso K. lives close to Shahrituz, Tajikistan. She is thirty-seven and married with three children. Her husband is a wedding organizer. Nurinisso has grown and sold vegetables for over five years. She is asking for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer.


Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Tahan

texts.en: Tahan is married and is 40 years old.  He is a carpenter who has owned his own carpentry shop since 2000. He is the only provider for his family. Tahan is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy additional tools for his shop in order to increase his family's income.

loans.use: to buy additional tools

loans.name: Sègbégnon Nathalie

texts.fr: Z. Sègbégnon Nathalie est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sègbégnon Nathalie est mariée à PADONOU Antonin et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Sègbégnon Nathalie vit avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, depuis 15 ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Sègbégnon Nathalie n'a pas été à l'école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Sègbégnon Nathalie vend des feuilles d'emballage d'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs), des nattes en raphia et également de la boisson alcoolisée locale à Kpondéhou. Sègbégnon Nathalie s'approvisionne à Djèrègbé, non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. C'est depuis douze ans que Sègbégnon Nathalie exerce cette activité. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien et sans difficulté ses crédits. Sègbégnon Nathalie sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour agrandir davantage son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Z. Sègbégnon Nathalie was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to PADONOU Antonin and is the mother of four children who are all in school.  She has been living with her husband and children in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou for fifteen years.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  Sègbégnon Nathalie has not been to school.  To support herself and her family, she sells leaves for wrapping akassa (a local food made with cornstarch), raffia mats, and also the local alcoholic drink in Kpondéhou.  She stocks up in Djèrègbé, not far from Porto-Novo (the administrative capital of Benin).  She has been in this business for a dozen years.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans without a problem.  She's requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy leaves for wrapping "akassa" and some raffia mats

loans.name: Nasim

texts.en: H. Nasim is married with 4 children. Given the lack of jobs and the difficulty of earning enough to support his family, ten years ago Nasim and his wife started their own business selling groceries. The quality of their service and daily efforts helped them retain customers. Nasim wants to boost his sales and therefore he is requesting a loan for 4000 Somoni to purchase merchandise. This is his fourth loan with IMON International. We look forward to more opportunities to assist him with his business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the foodstuff for increasing the range of goods for selling

loans.name: Joseph Macharia

texts.en: Joseph is married to Joyce and they have no children yet. Joseph was introduced to KADET through other existing clients and he has no previous credit history. He has been in the business of selling scrap metal for nine years and his other source of income is dairy farming. With the loan he has applied for he intends to add to his stock of scrap metal in his yard. Joseph’s business is situated near a market, where he sells products of scrap metal and things like metal boxes he makes for sale. With the extra profits he anticipates on earning he will add more stock of scrap metals. In future Joseph hopes to expand and open another outlet since he describes himself as hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add to his stock of scrap metal

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 25 year-old single man living with his parents. He has been working in construction since 2004 to earn money to help his father.

Today, Mohamad is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase additional wood and expand his business to meet the requirements of his clients and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood

loans.name: G. Véronique

texts.fr: K. G. Véronique est née en 1974 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ANAGO Josia, un revendeur, Véronique est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. C’est depuis douze ans que Véronique vit dans le quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou avec son mari et ses enfants. Véronique vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Véronique n’a pas été à l’école. C’est pourquoi depuis onze ans, Véronique vend à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, des bois de chauffage. Véronique exerce comme activité secondaire, la vente de condiments de sauce (tomate, oignons, etc.). C’est à Adja au Mono et à Ekpè, sur la route de Porto-Novo (capitale administrative du Bénin) que Véronique s’approvisionne. Véronique est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue d’agrandir davantage son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle, Véronique sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. G. Véronique was born in 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to ANAGO Josia, a retailer, she is the mother of three children who are all in school.  For twelve years, she has been living in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou with her husband and children.  She works in aid of her husband to meet family expenses.  Véronique has not been to school.  That's why, for eleven years, she has been selling firewood at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  Her secondary business involves selling sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, etc.)  She gets her supplies in Adja in Mono and in Ekpè, on the road to Porto-Novo (the administrative capital of Benin).  Véronique is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  With the aim of expanding her business further and growing her customer base, she's requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood wholesale

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en: Kassem is a 32-year-old married man and father of 3 children who still attend school. He has been working in the construction sector since 2004 and has  considerable experience in the field. Today, Kassem is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase scaffolding needed for his business.

loans.use: to purchase scaffolding

loans.name: Sonagnon Félicienne

texts.fr: Z. Sonagnon Félicienne est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sonagnon Félicienne est mariée à KOUNNOU Valentin, un commerçant. Le couple a quatre enfants en charge, dont trois sont leurs enfants. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. C'est depuis 13 ans que Sonagnon Félicienne vit avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Il y a neuf ans de cela que Sonagnon Félicienne vend des produits divers (savons, insecticides, biscuits, sucre, lait, pâtes alimentaires, sardines, riz, huile végétale, etc.) à son domicile. Sonagnon Félicienne exerce comme activité secondaire, la vente du charbon de bois à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Sonagnon Félicienne s'approvisionne. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse sans retard ses crédits. Sonagnon Félicienne sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un cinquième crédit afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'augmenter sa marchandise pour faire face à la demande importante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Z. Sonagnon Félicienne was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to KOUNNOU Valentin, a merchant.  The couple has four children to support.  Three of them are theirs;  some of them are in school.  For thirteen years, she has been living with her children and husband in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  For nine years, Sonagnon Félicienne has been selling a variety of goods (soaps, insecticides, cookies, sugar, milk, pasta, sardines, rice, vegetable oil, etc.) out of her home.  She has a secondary business selling charcoal out of her home.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans without delay.  She's requesting from ALIDé a fifth loan for increasing her working capital and for augmenting her merchandise to cope with the substantial customer demand. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods (boxes of pasta, sugar, canned foods, milk, rice)

loans.name: Catherine Namisango ‘S Group

texts.en: Catherine is a 45 years old, married, with eight children between the ages of 3 and 25. Six of her children still attend to school. She owns a one room house where she lives with four other people. Catherine also takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs expenses traveling to and from villages in the Luwero District, one of the central districts of Uganda, to buy charcoal,. She works in a semi urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.She uses public transport to and from Luwero. Catherine works seven days a week.  She receives an average of 25 customers a day and sells to people at both retail and wholesale. Her major challenges include the ever increasing prices of charcoal, the rainy season which hinders her customers' ability to reach her, and ever increasing  transport costs. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding her family and medication.  She has been in this business for ten years and joined MCDT ten years ago. This will be her twentieth loan. Catherine joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of second hand clothes . She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en: A. Rahima is 49 years old. She is married and the mother of three adorable children. Rahima has a grocery store which she tends to herself, in addition to caring for her family and her home. She started her small business 8 years ago with financial support from her husband who has been selling spare parts for automobiles for some time. Her reason for starting the business was to increase her large family’s income and the business has been gradually growing ever since. In order to grow her business she requests for a loan of 5000 Somoni. Rahima is planning to spend the loan purchasing more goods to sell thus increasing her variety of merchandise. She thanks everybody who decided to support her. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing goods to increase variety of merchandise

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is a 35 year married woman with four children between the ages of 10 and 16.  Both of her children attend school. She rents a two room house where she is lives with four other people. Hadjah also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  She works in a semi urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. Hadjah works seven days a week .She receives an average of 20 customers a day at her charcoal stall in Naguru. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever increasing prices of charcoal in Uganda due to fuel prices. She has owned her business for over five years and has been a member of MCDT for five years. This will be her tenth loan. Hadjah joined MCDT because it was close to her home and it was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspires to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Barno

texts.en:
E. Barno is 47 is years old. She is hard working and confident. She is married and has three children. Her husband receives very low wages and they could not afford all of the family expenses. That’s why Barno decided it necessary to start working also. She began to sell  foodstuffs in her grocery store with the help of her elder son. The business is stable and allows her to improve the living conditions of her family. Today Barno is asking for a loan of $1200 USD that she will use in the extension of her business to be able to offer better service to her clients and to improve other aspects of her store. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. loans.use: Purchasing  foodstuffs in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.en:
As the father of four children, Ravshan decided to start looking to start the kind of business that could yield enough money to support his wife and family for the long term, particularly so that his children can finish their studies. For this reason, he took what little savings he had and started his own bread “lepeshka,” a bakery business at home. With only a few utensils and clients but with faith and enthusiasm, he has made his business successful by growing a loyal clientele little by little. However, Ravshan wishes to offer his clients better services so that they do not seek other competing businesses. He also wants to be able to attract more clients. He is therefore requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 USD. With this money, Ravshan will be able to buy more products for making lepeshka and will be able to make improvements to his offerings. With these improvements, Ravshan expects to attract more clients and will be capable of supporting his family and continuing to fund his children’s studies. His goal is to be able to offer a better future to his family.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To buy flour and ingredients for the baking of lepeshka.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.fr: K. Ruth est née en 1975. Mariée et mère de cinq enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge, Ruth vit avec son mari et ses enfants à PK11 à Sèmè-Podji sur la route de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. C'est depuis 8 ans que Ruth vit dans ce quartier. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés. Ruth vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Ruth a très tôt abandonné l'école. Il y a deux ans de cela que Ruth mène comme activité, la vente de tissus, habits et chaussures par le système de distribution. Ruth s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo pays voisin du Bénin, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ruth n'a jamais obtenu de crédit à ALIDé. C'est pour renforcer son commerce en l'agrandissant afin de faire face à la demande de ses clients, que Ruth sollicite ce premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Madame Ruth K. was born in 1975. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in her care. She lives with her husband and children in PK11 in Sèmè-Podji on the way to Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin; she has lived in this neighborhood for eight years. All her children attend school. Madame K. helps her husband out with the household expenses. She abandoned her own schooling at a young age. For two years she has been selling fabrics, clothes and shoes through the distribution system. She stocks up in Lomé in Togo, a neighboring country to Benin, and in Benin's international market, Dantokpa. Madame K. has not had a loan from Kiva Field Partner ALIDé before. She is requesting this first loan from ALIDé to strengthen and grow her business to meet her clients' needs.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of fabric and pairs of shoes

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba K. is 37 years old, married and has two children. She is a teacher in a local school. Considering the low wages teachers earn, Nasiba started her own business of processing and selling apricots nine years ago. Dried fruit, especially dried apricots, are very popular in Tajikistan and are good for one’s health as well. Considering the constant demand for these dried fruits, Nasiba’s apricot business is quite successful and has resulted in a significant and stable income benefitting her household and the education of her dear children.

Today Nasiba is requesting a loan of $1500 USD. She is going to use the loan to purchase more apricots with the purpose of expanding the range of apricot products she sells. Nasiba expresses her gratitude to everyone who supports her. Help this woman of much strength and courage to keep working.

About Tajikistan:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture and new Western cultures and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

About IMON International:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have access to reasonable financial services. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase additional apricots for her business.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr: S. Chantal est mariée à DADE Fidèle, un agent au Port de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Chantal est mère de six enfants tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à sa charge. Chantal réside depuis une trentaine d’année au quartier Hindé à Cotonou. C’est avec son mari et ses enfants qu’elle vit. Chantal vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Ayant abandonné très tôt l’école, Chantal s’est mise dans la vente de paniers et de balais à son domicile, afin de faire face à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. C’est depuis quinze ans que Chantal mène cette activité. Chantal s’approvisionne à Comé au Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Pour renforcer son activité  et satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Chantal sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Chantal S. is married to Fidèle Dade, an agent at the Port of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Chantal is the mother of six children, all in school, of whom four are in her care. Chantal has lived for thirty years in the Hindé area of Cotonou. She lives with her husband and children. Chantal helps her husband in providing for the family. Having abandoned her schooling very early on, Chantal began selling baskets and brooms at her home in order to meet her needs and those of her children. She has run this business for fifteen years. Chantal gets her supplies at Comé in Benin. She is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and has repaid all her loans properly. To strengthen her business and better satisfy her customers, Chantal is seeking a fourth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baskets in bulk

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses M. is forty years old and is married to Jane Nyaruiru. They have three children going to school. He has been operating a tailoring shop in Naivasha town since 2004.

Moses was introduced to KADET by a friend. Having paid off his first loan with no problems, he is requesting a second from KADET. He plans to buy new fabric so that he can make more clothes to sell in his shop. In the future Moses would like to start selling fabric wholesale.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy fabric for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Burkhon

texts.en:
Burkhon M. is a 25-year-old young man who dedicates his time to driving a taxi and a microbus. He is not married, but the need for an additional source of income for his large family forced him to start his own business. Burkhon has about two years of experience in the public transportation field. Demands for his service are rather high since there are so many people who need it.

Burkhon must maintain his vehicle since this is the tool of his trade. So now Burkhon is counting on your help. He is requesting a loan of $3000 USD to purchase spare parts and winter tires for his microbus. With your support, Burkhon will continue to prosper in his business and so support his brother and sister in their education.

About Tajikistan:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture and new Western cultures and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

About IMON International:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have access to reasonable financial services. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy spare parts and winter tires to maintain his microbus.

loans.name: Nouha

texts.en:
Nouha is a 41-year-old unmarried woman living with her mother and sister. Since 1995, she has owned a mini-market in her town where she sells items to people from her own village as well as from neighboring villages. She and her sister work hard, hoping to improve living conditions for themselves and their parents.

Today, Nouha is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 in order to buy more merchandise for sale. With the increased sales, she expects to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for sale

loans.name: Rébecca

texts.fr: B. Rébecca est née vers 1949 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Rébecca est mariée et est  mère de six enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants de Rébecca sont scolarisés. Rébecca vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. C'est depuis 25 ans que Rébecca vit à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Rébecca n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis une vingtaine d'année, Rébecca vend du charbon de bois à son domicile. A cela s'ajoute la vente d'huile d'arachide qu'elle exerce de façon secondaire. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rébecca s'approvisionne. Rébecca est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. C'est pour renforcer son activité en l'agrandissant davantage, et pour satisfaire sa clientèle, que Rébecca sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rébecca B. was born around 1949 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Rébecca is married and has six children, of whom three are in her care. All of Rébecca's children are in school. Rébecca lives alone with her children and supports the family by herself. For 25 years, Rébecca has lived in Ekpè, in the town of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Rébecca never went to school. For twenty years, Rébecca has been selling charcoal at her home. To this, she has also added the sale of peanut oil, which she runs as a secondary business. It is at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, that Rébecca gets her supplies. Rébecca is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid all her loans properly. To strengthen her business by further enlarging it and to satisfy her customers, Rébecca is seeking a sixth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Shoira

texts.en:
S. Shoira is 32 years old and lives with her husband and their four children. She works every day, starting very early in the morning, hoping to set aside enough money to improve her family's living conditions and to achieve her goal of having all four of her children successfully finish school and enter university.

Her business is located near her house. She sells children's clothes. Thanks to the support of her spouse and through her own efforts, Shoira has been able to expand her business, which began with very little inventory and in a small space, and which now has a bigger space and a larger clientele. With this loan in the amount of 4,000 Somoni, she will buy a greater variety of clothing for sale, specifically by adding women's clothing to her inventory. By offering a loan to his dedicated entrepreneur, you can be an important part of the growth of Shoira’s business.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To add women's clothing to her inventory in order to increase her range of goods for sale

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein has been working as a home painter since 2003. He is unmarried and takes care of his mother, with whom he resides. Today, Hussein is requesting a loan in the amount of $500. He wants to buy an air compressor in order to improve and eventually expand his business.

loans.use: To buy an air compressor to improve and eventually expand his business

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila J. sells fresh vegetables in the market. She is requesting a loan in order to buy other goods to offer for sale, such as salt, sugar, and rice. Laila is 40 years old and is divorced. She has four children, all of whom attend school. With the profits she expects from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to live in with her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy other goods to offer for sale, such as salt, sugar, and rice

loans.name: Michael Ombaka

texts.en:
Michael O., 25 years old, is a barber. His wife is named Roselyda Makoha. Michael has owned a barber shop for the last two years and generates a monthly profit of about Ksh. 10,000.

To supplement his income from the barber shop, O. has a side business: he operates a cafeteria in Shanzu. He was introduced to KADET by existing clients who encouraged him to apply for a loan. He would like to see his cafeteria business grow and he believes that this loan will boost his endeavors in the right direction.

In the future, he wants to be a commercial horticultural farmer while also running his cafeteria business and continuing to work as a barber.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to empower its clients economically by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To boost his cafeteria business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is an 18-year-old single man living with his parents and 6 siblings. In 2008 he started painting houses as a profession, which started by painting a friend's house and Ali ended up liking the work. Today, he hopes to borrow $1,200 in order to purchase a new air compressor so he can become more efficient.

loans.use: to purchase a new air compressor

loans.name: Folayèmi A. Wossilatou

texts.fr: L. Folayèmi A. Wossilatou est née en 1957 et est mariée à YESSOUFOU Mazoukou, un commerçant. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés, mais seulement deux sont à leur charge. Wossilatou réside depuis 25 ans au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Wossilatou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Wossilatou a abandonné l'école depuis le cours primaire. Il y a 20 ans de cela que Wossilatou mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits de mercerie dans sa boutique  qui fait face à la voie menant à la mairie de Dandji à Cotonou. Wossilatou s'approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. C'est pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et renforcer son activité pendant la période des fêtes, que Wossilatou sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Folayèmi A. Wossilatou L. was born in 1957 and is married to Mazoukou Yessoufou, a shopkeeper. The couple have five children, all in school, but only two of whom are in their care. Wossilatou has lived for 25 years in the Dandji area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Wossilatou helps her husband provide for the family. Wossilatou abandoned her studies in primary school. For 20 years since then, Wossilatou has run a business selling various sewing and dressmaking supplies in her store, which faces the road leading to the Dandji town hall in Cotonou. Wossilatou gets her supplies in Nigeria, a country bordering Benin, and at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is a longtime client of ALIDÉ who has repaid all her loans properly. To increase her working capital and strengthen her business during the holiday period, Wossilatou is seeking a sixth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various sewing and dressmaking supplies

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea G. is currently in the business of selling used clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase other items like shoes and belts for sale. Lea is 32 years old and widowed. She has 3 children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase items like shoes and belts for sale

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 44-year old man living with his wife and four children. In 1990 he bought a piece of land and made it into a parking lot to make money to be able to feed his children. Today, Ahmad is requesting to borrow $1,200 in order to fix the land by covering it with new cement.

loans.use: To fix the land he uses as a parking lot

loans.name: Juliah

texts.en: Juliah M. is a 23 year old medical nurse and is married to Pius Chovi. The couple lives in Shanzu, Mombasa where Juliah runs a pharmacy (chemist's shop). She has been in this business for two years and has been able offer her services to the local residents. Juliah intends to increase her supplies of antibiotics, analgesics and antiflammatories in her pharmacy with this first loan that she is accessing in KADET. She hopes to establish an even bigger pharmacy in future to be able to reach out to the communities around Shanzu, and that she hopes will be a reality with subsequent KADET loans. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy antibiotics, analgesics and antiflammatories.

loans.name: Myriam

texts.fr: Y. Myriam est née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Myriam est mariée à ALLABI Loudous, un Juriste. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Dandji à Cotonou, depuis dix ans. Myriam vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Myriam est allée à l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Depuis cinq ans de cela, Myriam vend des mèches, des chaussures, des bijoux et des produits cosmétiques dans sa boutique sise à Lokokoukoumé à Cotonou. C'est au Nigéria et à Lomé au Togo, deux Etats voisins du Bénin, que Myriam s'approvisionne. Myriam a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. C'est en vue de renforcer davantage son activité pour pouvoir mieux satisfaire sa clientèle que Myriam sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Myriam Y. was born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Myriam is married to Loudous Allabi, a lawyer. The couple have two children, both in school. The family has lived in the Dandji area of Cotonou for ten years. Myriam helps her husband provide for the family. Myriam attended school up to the secondary level. For five years, Myriam has been selling hair extensions, shoes, jewelry, and cosmetics at her store located in Lokokoukoumé in Cotonou. It is in Nigeria and in Lomé, Togo, two countries bordering Benin, that Myriam gets her supplies. Myriam has already obtained one loan from ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which she repaid properly. With the goal of further strengthening her business to better satisfy her customers, Myriam is seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions, pairs of shoes, and cosmetics

loans.name: Anne  Wanjiru

texts.en:
Ann is married to Jackson and they have two children named Claire and Clive.

Ann was introduced to KADET by existing clients and is now asking for her second loan. She sells clothes in an open air market in the Eastlands area of Nairobi, something she has been doing for eight years now. Her other source of income is hairdressing at the same place. The market is normally very busy and she has applied for a loan to add more merchandise like skirts which will tremendously boost her business. With the extra profits she intends to own her own salon thus increasing her income base. She describes herself as hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase stock of ladies skirts in the open air market.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 27 years old and runs a shop selling women's clothing. She has been in this business for three years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of Kes. 50,000 in order to add stock for sale during the upcoming festive holiday season.

Jane describes herself as a very hardworking, honest, and ambitious businesswoman. She has learned to run her business properly through taking training at Faulu.

In the future, she hopes to own her own home, learn to drive a car, and have children.

loans.use: To add inventory for sale during the upcoming holiday season

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en:
Alaa is a 20-year-old man living with his parents and three siblings. Six years ago, his father started teaching him how to work in construction. Once he understood the process, he started working on his own, hoping to increase and perhaps even double the household income.

Today, Alaa is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200 in order to purchase new tools.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his construction business

loans.name: Agustin

texts.en:
Agustin A. is 53 years old and has been married for 31 years to Pelagia Ortega, who is 54 years old. They have 6 children of which three are already married and living independently. The other three live still live at home. Agustin has been a trader for 4 years. He began his business with money he earned from selling produce that he grows, such as sugarcane, cassava, watermelon and beans. 

Agustin will use this loan for the purchase of products like oil, noodles, flour, shirt, soaps, insecticides, coal, and other beverages in general. This would allow him to increase his stock of merchandise and thus offer his customers greater variety.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Ayapaw

texts.en: Ayapaw A. is currently in the business of selling rice and sugar in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of sugar and rice to sell. Ayapaw is 35 years old and is married. She has 6 children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a supermarket. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy bags of sugar and rice

loans.name: Pius

texts.en:
Pius C. is 32 years old and single. He transports people and goods on his motorbike in Mombasa's Changamwe area, something he has been doing for two years now. Pius has been able cover his living expenses with his income and has also managed to accumulate some savings. The location of his business is good and his services are in constant demand.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is now in his group. This will be his first loan. With a combination of the loan and his own savings, Pius plans to purchase a second motorbike to increase his daily income.

He hopes that one day he will become a leader in the transport industry and own several trucks. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 26-year-old married man with two young children. Twelve years ago he started transporting goods for a store in the neighborhood and in 2004 when he could afford to buy his own van he started a business transporting goods for several stores in his village. Today, Ali is requesting a loan of $1,200 in order to replace the trunk of the van so that he can safely and cleanly transport goods.

loans.use: to change the trunk of the van

loans.name: Médégnonmi

texts.fr: D. Médégnonmi est née en 1958 et est mariée à AMANGANNON Janvier, un militaire. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge. Il y a 25 ans que Médégnonmi réside à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Médégnonmi supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Médégnonmi n'a pas été à l'école. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Médégnonmi vend des tissus, des chaussures, des savons, du riz, etc. par le système de distribution. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Médégnonmi s'approvisionne. Médégnonmi est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits et qui connait une évolution dans ses activités. En vue de renforcer davantage son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Médégnonmi sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Médégnonmi D. was born in 1958 and is married to Janvier Amangannon, a serviceman. The couple have four children, all in school and still in their care. For 25 years, Médégnonmi has lived in Djeffa in the town of Sèmè-Podji, Benin. Médégnonmi provides for the family with her husband. Médégnonmi did not go to school. For ten years, Médégnonmi has sold fabric, shoes, soap, rice, etc. through the distribution system. It is at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and in Lomé, Togo, a country bordering Benin, that Médégnonmi gets her supplies. Médégnonmi is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid her loans properly and has seen her business develop. With the goal of further strengthening her business to better satisfy her customers, Médégnonmi is seeking a sixth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of fabric and bags of rice

loans.name: Ikisa

texts.en: Ikisa J. is currently in the business of selling beer and drinks like sodas, water, juice, etc. and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer for sell. Ikisa is 50 years old and widowed. She has 3 children who no longer attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar and restaurant. BRAC About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more crates of beer for sell

loans.name: Mirvat

texts.en:
Mirvat is a 26-year-old woman who lives with her husband. Five years ago, she started working with her friend in a beauty salon, and in 2007 she started working on her own from home.

Today, Mirvat is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200. She wants to use the loan to purchase new utensils.

loans.use: To purchase new utensils for use in her beauty salon business

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Josephine W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Grace. She is 41 years old and is married with two children, ages 10 and 24. Her youngest child attends school and her eldest is a high school graduate. Josephine also cares for a nephew. She herself dropped out of high school due to conditions of civil unrest, but she had always wanted to get into business.

Josephine lives in the ELWA community on the southern outskirts of Monrovia. She works on Front Street in downtown Monrovia. Her business is the sales of used clothing. She buys used clothing and sells these in retail. The quality of her goods is high, and she offers affordable prices in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. She started her business with LD1000.00, which was given to her by her sister.

She has been running this business for 12 years and hopes to open a building materials store in the future.

Josephine needs this loan to add stock and improve her business.

She dreams of becoming a well-established businesswoman and giving her children a better education.

loans.use: To add inventory and improve her business

loans.name: Bibiane

texts.en:
Bibiane is 31 years old, single, and she takes care of one dependent who is 16 years old. Bibiane lives in the Nyarugenge district in Kigali, Rwanda's capital city. Bibiane has been working as wholesaler of charcoal for 2 successful years. She works long hours in her job, from 6 AM to 8 PM six days per week.

This is the first time for Bibiane to request a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. When she is lent this sum, she hopes that it will allow her to buy a greater volume of charcoal at lower prices and give her some extra working capital to operate her business. She also hopes to increase the number of her customers and make more sales and profit. If successful, this will allow her to invest in the education of her dependent and in addition, she will be able to build a more secure future for herself.

loans.use: More charcoal for sale and general working capital

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline L. is currently in the business of selling rice and sugar in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal to sell. Jackline is 38 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant. BRAC About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase bags of  charcoal

loans.name: Hammed

texts.en: Hammed is 45 years old and married with 5 children. His children are excelling in school. To earn a living, he sells building materials at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business for a long time. He sells for long hours to meet the needs of his immediate family members. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. Hammed  is requesting for a loan amount 150,000 NGN to purchase more building materials to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Margaret Kaloki

texts.en:
Margaret M. and her husband, David, have three children: John, Amos, and Jennifer who are 19, 16, and 8 years old respectively. Margaret operates a grocery and a charcoal business which she has done for three years. The client's area of business is within the Kibera slum and her customers are low income earners.

The client was introduced to KADET by existing clients, and she will use the loan she has applied for to add more stock of fruits, charcoal and eggs to her business. With he extra profits the client intends to buy kerosene for sale.

Her future hope is to purchase a piece of land and use it to build rental houses, something she believes she can do because of her hardworking nature.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock of fruits, charcoal and eggs.

loans.name: Interest Come First Group

texts.en:
Philip L. Z. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called "Interest Comes First." He is 42 years old, married with 5 children who are between 7 and 16 and whose educational levels range from kindergarten to 4th grade. He dropped out in 10th grade due to financial difficulties.

Philip lives in the Lakpazee community and work on Water street, downtown in the city of Monrovia, Liberia. His business is selling shoes. He buys shoes wholesale and sell them retail on Water Street. He has been running this business for 19 years, and hoping to improve to a store in the future. Philip sells quality shoes and talks to his customers in a kind manner in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. He started his business with LD6000.00 he saved when working for a friend who was also selling shoes.

Philip needs this loan to increase his goods to improve business. He dreams of giving his children a better education .

loans.use: Philip needs this loan to increase his goods to improve business.

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: R. Martine est née en 1970 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Martine est mariée à AHONOUKOU Paul, un prestataire de service. Le couple a six enfants en charge, dont cinq sont leurs propres enfants. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. Martine vit depuis 10 ans à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Martine n'a fait que le cours primaire à l'école. Il y a 10 ans de cela que Martine vend de la nourriture (ailerons frits accompagnés de piron fait à base de farine de manioc). A côté de cela, Martine vend des boissons au Parc MIVVO à Sèmè-Podji. Martine fait ses approvisionnements à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Martine sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Martine R. was born in 1970 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Martine is married to Paul Ahonoukou, a contractor. The couple have six children in their care, of whom five are their own. Only some of the children are in school. For 10 years, Martine has lived in Djeffa in the town of Sèmè-Podji, Benin with her husband and children. The couple provide for the family together. Martine only completed her primary education. For 10 years, Martine has sold food (fried wings accompanied by 'piron' - a type of food paste made from manioc flour). Besides this, Martine sells beverages at the Mivvo Park in Sèmè-Podji. Martine gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) and has repaid her loans properly. Martine is seeking a fifth loan through ALIDÉ in order to increase her working capital and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wings, bags of manioc flour, and sauce condiments

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah is 50 years old, married to Kabebe Wambui and they have three school going children. She has been running her food joint in Naivasha town for the last three years.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan after paying her first loan very well. She plans to expand her restaurant business by selling produce on the side and that's why she has applied for this loan. She will sell fruits, vegetables and dry food stuff from her extended business. She foresees a bright future once this new business grows as she will become financially stable and be able to buy a piece of land and build her own home. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Open a grocery shop on the side

loans.name: Fatayi

texts.en: G. sells beef at retail prices in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He is 35 years old and married with two children. He sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on his table to feed his children. This is the high season for his business and he hopes to make more profits during this season. G. is asking for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more beef to sell. He is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Charles Wambua

texts.en:
Charles is a married man.  He and his wife Florence have five children together: P., Mutisya, Musyoki, Mouo and Muli.

Charles was introduced to KADET through other KADET clients, and he is now taking out his second loan with them.  He has been running a general shop for two years, and with this loan he intends to add stock of sugar, maize flour and charcoal to his inventory. His business is situated in a slum area which is nevertheless vibrant and has many customers. With the extra profits from his loan he plans to sell charcoal wholesale.  Charles believes he is hardworking, and also hopes to develop a piece of land and build rental houses to earn an income from the rent.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services which will improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. More information about KADET is available on their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: to add stock of sugar, maize flour and charcoal to his inventory

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas O. is 45 years old and married to Roseline Apondi.  He has been running a welding shop in Naivasha town for the last 16 years.  He was introduced to KADET through a friend, and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan to buy welding materials in bulk, including welding wire.  He hopes to see his business grow, thus giving him financial freedom.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services which will improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. More information about KADET is available on their website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: to buy welding materials in bulk

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth sells cooking oil and food spices at retail prices to her customers. She is 38 years old and married with three children. She is a friendly and hardworking woman. Her friendliness attracts customers to her shop. Janeth is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more food spices and cooking oil to sell. She hopes to sell her goods at wholesale prices to her customers in the future. 
Janeth says thanks to all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil and food spices to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph operates a taxi business in Naivasha town. He has been doing this for three years. Joseph is 30 years old, married to Beth Muthoni, and they have a four year old baby who is in nursery school. He was introduced to KADET by a friend. This will be his first loan with KADET and he plans to use the cash to repaint his car and buy new tires. His future plan is to buy another vehicle. He will employ someone to drive it for him as a taxi. He also plans to buy a piece of land for farming activities.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To repaint his taxi and buy new tires

loans.name: Mutie

texts.en:
Mutie M., age 38, has two successful businesses. His primary business is his restaurant, called "Peter's Cave", which is in the residential area of Chaanoi in Mombassa. He has also begun a transportation business offering motorbike services (called boda boda in Kenya). His current bike is in the photo. He has an employee run his restaurant while he is out offering motorcycle transport. This loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings is to purchase another bike and expand that part of his business.

Mutie is married and has four children: two boys and two girls ranging in age from 2 to 13 years old. His dreams for his family are to bring them up properly and provide a good education – to him, it is the basis for everything. In terms of his business, he would like to continue to expand both the boda boda and the restaurant. He also sees opportunities buying houses as rental properties in his growing area in Mombassa.

Mutie says he provides good services to his clients. He is the secretary of his borrowing group, "Jitegemee".

loans.use: To expand transport business by buying another bike

loans.name: Firdaus

texts.en:
Mrs. Firdaus A. is 23 years old and married to S. A., a businessman. They have one young child by the name of A. Hakim and they reside in Bamburi, Mombasa.

Firdaus A. will use her loan from KADET to import clothes from Saudi Arabia for her secondary business. Mrs. A. was introduced to KADET by an existing client and says that she is very happy to be associated with the institution.

In future Firdaus hopes to have a larger space for her game zone and video-showing hall so that she will be able to accommodate more customers. She also wants to diversify the import business in a big way.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Import clothes from Saudi Arabia for her secondary business

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen A. is a 46-year-old married mother of one child. She lives with her family in Chaani, Mombasa where she is a tailor. Hellen has been running her tailoring shop for six years and it is a success.
