She joined KADET recently and is glad to be accessing her first loan to finance her shop. With the loan she plans to buy more garments to be able to satisfy the customers she serves, who are mainly area residents.

In future she hopes to become an established and sought-after clothing designer.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more garments for the tailoring shop she runs

loans.name: Jackson Kijiwe

texts.en:
Jackson is a 25-year-old farmer who resides in Malindi town, together with his young wife Agnes and two sons: Daudi and Antony Kijiwe.

He has been farming for the last three years and plans to increase his acreage from one acre to three acres so as to be self-sustainable. He is a KADET client and he has applied for a loan with which he plans to buy 3 gallons of petrol, hybrid seeds, fertilizers CAN and DAP and pay for labour that will be done on his farm.

Jackson dreams of being able to educate his children comfortably and he describes himself as quiet and easy-going.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buy petrol, hybrid seeds and fertlizers and pay for labour

loans.name: Alimatu

texts.en:
Alimatu is married with 4 children. She is 32 years old. She sells tomatoes, peppers, and yams at retail prices to her customers. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells long hours to meet the basic needs and necessities of the family.

Alimatu needs the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more yams and peppers to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is saying “thanks” to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yams and peppers to sell

loans.name: Ebenezer Group

texts.en:
Joseph B. M. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Ebenezer'. He is 35 years old, a single father of 2 children aged 6 and 12 years old. Their educational levels are kindergarten and 5th grade. He is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to financial difficulties.

Joseph lives on Crown Hill, downtown Monrovia, and works on Broad Street, the most popular street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. His business is the sale of apples. He buys apples from wholesalers and sells retail on Broad Street. He has been running this business for 19 years, and he is hoping to expand it into a shop in the future.

Joseph sells good apples and talks to his customers in a good manner in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. He started selling with LD400.00 that was given to him by his father.

Joseph needs this loan to improve business. He dreams of giving his children a better education for a better future.

loans.use: to expand and improve business

loans.name: Georges

texts.fr: D. Georges est né en 1978 à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Georges est marié et père de deux enfants qui sont scolarisés. Georges a un autre enfant à sa charge. Georges réside avec ses enfants et sa femme, à Ekpè depuis 8 ans. La femme de Georges l'aide à supporter les charges de la famille. Georges a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Georges mène comme activité, la vente de cartes de recharges téléphonique dans sa boutique à Ekpè. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Ekpè, que Georges s'approvisionne. Georges a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et l'a bien remboursé. Dans l'optique d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité, Georges sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Georges D. was born in 1978 in Ekpè, in the town of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Georges is married and is the father of two children who are in school. Georges also has one other child in his care. Georges has lived with his children and wife in Ekpè for 8 years. Georges' wife helps him in providing for the family. Georges ended his education in secondary school. To meet his needs and those of his children, Georges runs a business selling rechargeable phone cards in his store in Ekpè. It is at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and also in Ekpè, that Georges gets his supplies. Georges has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which he repaid properly. With the goal of increasing his working capital and strengthening his business, Georges is seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rechargeable phone cards

loans.name: Jean Nepomscene

texts.en:
Jean Nepomscene is 20 years old and single, and he lives in the western province of Rwanda which is approximately 3 hours' drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here, Jean Nepomscene has had a shop selling a variety of goods for the past 2 years. Even at a relatively young age, he is proving to be a successful businessperson and loves having his own shop. The hours of his business require that he work from 7 AM to 8PM every day.

Jean Nepomscene employs 2 people as helpers. The nature of his business is somewhat capital intensive and in order to grow, Jean Nepomscene is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his shop through purchasing larger quantities of bulk goods and supplies at lower costs. This additional capital will allow him to get the best pricing and adequately satisfy the product needs and wants of his customers. As any entrepreneur, Jean Nepomscene hopes to make more profit, which will help him to build a secure future for himself.

loans.use: More inventory and more varieties of goods

loans.name: Bakyala Kwekulakulanya Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en:
S. Amina is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is 42 years old and married with 9 children aged 23 – 9 years, of whom 6 are still in school; she takes care of 14 dependents.

Amina has a clothing store in Kinyolo that has been operational for 10 years, and she is able to make 60,000/= as profits a week. Her business is mostly affected by the ever changing seasons, high price of stock plus the high rent for her store. She ensures that she has enough stock for her customers to choose from, plus having competitive prices. She hopes to expand her store in future as well as to have an educated family. Amina needs a loan to help increase her working capital since she spent most of it on school fees.

loans.use: buying more clothes for resale

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose sells sarongs and lace fabrics at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is a hard-working woman. She is 30 years old and single, without children. She hopes for the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs and lace to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more sales during this season. She expresses her gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and lace to sell

loans.name: Bakyala Kwekulakulanya Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en:
S. Charles is a hard-working man and the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is 53 years old and a devoted married man with 12 children aged 29 – 10 of whom 2 are still in school; he also cares for 7 dependents including grandchildren.

Charles has had a business selling 'waragi', a local brew, since 1984 and his idea of getting loans was to help improve the quality of his 'waragi'. The main challenges affecting his business are the debtors who take a long time to pay for the products, poor quality raw inputs in instances where he cannot afford to purchase the good ones, as well as the lack of charcoal because of the rainy season.

After having access to the loans, Charles is now able to make quality 'waragi' in addition to his improved customer care. He has a hope of ensuring that all his children attend school. He needs a loan to help purchase more raw materials like bananas, yeast, and firewood for making 'waragi'.

loans.use: Buying bananas, yeast, drums and firewood for making 'waragi'

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: K. Célestine est née vers 1963 et est mariée à FOLI Jonas, un forgeron. Le couple a six enfants tous scolarisés, mais trois seulement sont à leur charge. Célestine vit depuis douze ans avec ses enfants et son mari à PK11 à Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Célestine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Célestine n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Célestine mène comme activité, la vente de farine de blé en sachets, sardines, vinaigre, allumette, défrisants, pâtes alimentaires, oeufs, etc. C'est au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Célestine s'approvisionne. Célestine a 8 ans d'expérience dans ce domaine. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Célestine sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d'agrandir son commerce et de satisfaire davantage ses clients.
texts.en:
Célestine K. was born around 1963 and is married to Jonas Foli, a blacksmith. The couple have six children, all in school, but only three of whom are in their care. For twelve years, Célestine has lived with her children and husband in PK11 in Sèmè-Podji, Benin. Célestine helps her husband provide for the family. Célestine never went to school. To meet her needs and those of her family, Célestine runs a business selling packets of wheat flour, sardines, vinegar, matches, hair straighteners, pasta, eggs, etc. It is in Nigeria, a country bordering Benin, that Célestine gets her supplies. Celestine has 8 years of experience in this area. She is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid her loans properly. Célestine is seeking a fifth loan through ALIDÉ in order to enlarge her business and to further satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of wheat flour, boxes of pasta, and trays of eggs

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha, a 42-year-old widow, has a poultry farm in Kisaasi with around 400 chickens. She has 150 broilers and 250 layers. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from Mengo-Kisenyi buying poultry feed. Aisha works seven days a week. She gets an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all kinds of people, both retail and wholesale. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever increasing price of chicken feed in Uganda.

Aisha has four children between the ages of 10 and 16. All her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she lives with four people. Aisha also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Aisha has been in business for over 15 years and with MCDT for 10 years – now on her 25th loan. Aisha joined MCDT because it is near her home and easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feed and 100 laying chicks. She dreams of owning 1500 chickens.

loans.use: To buy sacks of chicken feed and 100 laying chicks

loans.name: Cariñositas Group

texts.es: Victoria F. , casada y  madre de 3 niños, se dedica a el hilado de lana de vicuña y tejido de mantas, aprendió esta actividad de su madre, cuando ya tiene sus productos los vende a las tiendas que exponen mantas, con el préstamo ella desea comprar lana para seguir tejiendo, en esta actividad le colabora su hija. Victoria pertenece al grupo Cariñositas, que a su vez pertenece al Centro Focal Los Andes y espera estar mucho tiempo y lograr ahorros considerables, también ha visitado al  consultorio a hacerse el examen del PAP (papanicolau). Al igual que Victoria  las demás integrantes tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de comida, parrilla, joyas, víveres, ropa y trenzado de mantas. Necesitan el préstamo para incrementar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Victoria F., married and mother of three children, spins vicuña wool and weaves blankents. She learned this skill from her mother. When her items are done, she sells them to stores that exhibit blankets. With the loan she wants to buy more wool to continue weaving. Her daughter collaborates with her. Victoria is a member of the Cariñositas (The Affectionate Ones) group which, in turn, is a part of the Los Andes communal bank. She expects to be a member for a long time and to achieve considerable savings. She has also visited the health center to have her PAP (Papanicolau) smear. Like Victoria, the other group members have their own lines of work like: prepared meal sales, grills, jewelry, groceries, clothing, and blanket braiding. They need the funds to increase their working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital increase.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en:
Leonor is 41 years old, single, and works as a dairy farmer in Montecato, just outside of the city of Cochabamba. She also has a small grocery shop that she runs out of her home, where she sells snacks like crackers and soda. Leonor has been working as a dairy farmer for 12 years, beginning when she was a young teenager helping her mother.

Leonor is the youngest of her parents' children, so she is responsible for caring for her elderly parents. She has also been taking care of her nieces and nephews, as their parents left them under the care of Leonor's parents and never visit them nor pay for their education. Leonor makes sure the children attend school near her home, so she can look out for them. She is a very hard worker and works from very early morning hours, while also attending to the shop in her home and caring for her parents.

With this loan from CIDRE, Leonor is going to build a stable for her cows. Leonor's dream is to grow her milk production and earnings so that she can take care of her elderly parents well.

loans.use: Construction of a stable for dairy cows

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is 36 years old and has been married for 10 years. She has three children, ages 12, 10 and 2. Like many of CIDRE's borrowers, Miriam is a dairy cow farmer. Her farm is located in the Mantecato-Machamarca district outside of the city of Cochabamba.

Miriam is a very hard worker because, when she was little, her father died and she was left alone with her siblings in the care of her mother. Because of the financial strain, she and her siblings never finished high school. This was really hard for Miriam because her whole life she had dreamed of becoming a primary school teacher. She loves working with children and she has a lot of patience around children. She loves her own children so much – they are her reason for working. Miriam and her husband work hard to make sure that their children have a good education and will be able to finish high school and attend university.

With this loan from CIDRE, Miriam will purchase construction materials to build a stable for her livestock. Miriam hopes that this loan will help her to increase her milk production and protect her cows from illness, as they currently do not have a place to stay dry when it rains.

loans.use: Construction of a stable for dairy cows

loans.name: Benedetta Ndinda

texts.en:
Benedetta M. has been in the business of selling onions wholesale for three years. Her business location is within an estate and her clients are mainly retailers from the estates. She is married to Makau and they have one child, M., who is 8 years old. Benedetta was introduced to KADET through current clients and she is on her third loan from KADET. She intends to stock up on onions with this loan. With the extra profits, Benedetta intends to buy cereals for resale as a secondary business. Benedetta's hope is to educate her children to high levels of education. She describes herself as hardworking and honest.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To add stock to her food business

loans.name: Solange

texts.fr: D. Solange est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve et mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Solange vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les charges de la famille. C'est depuis 24 ans que Solange réside à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Solange n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Solange mène depuis 12 ans environs comme activité, la vente de poissons congelés à Abattoir dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. C'est au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Solange s'approvisionne. Solange est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité en complétant le stock de ses produits, et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients, Solange sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Solange D. was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widow and has three children in school, of whom one is in her care. Solange lives alone with her child and provides for her family by herself. For 24 years, Solange has lived in Agblangandan in the town of Sèmè-Podji, Benin. Solange never went to school. For about 12 years, Solange has run a business selling frozen fish at the abattoir in the town of Sèmè-Podji. It is in Nigeria, a country bordering Benin, that Solange gets her supplies. Solange is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid her loans properly. With the goal of strengthening her business by topping up her stock of products and better satisfying the demands of her customers, Solance is seeking a fifth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 boxes of fish

loans.name: Bilikisu

texts.en: Bilikisu is 30 years and married with a child. She is a focused, hard worker. She sells groceries and medicines at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a super market in the future. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for five years. S. hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to buy more groceries and medicines to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and medicines to sell

loans.name: Keith

texts.en:
Keith K. is a 58-year-old married father of four children. He lives in Mombasa's Mtopanga area where he is in the business of supplying firewood to residents and schools within Mtopanga and Shanzu. He has done this business for two years now. He also owns a hardware store in Shanzu, which supplements his daily income.

Keith learned of KADET through a marketing activity and was able to interact with the KADET officers. He is currently borrowing his first loan, which he intends to use to purchase firewood and for transport expenses. 

He hopes to own a truck to aid him in transportation of both the firewood and goods to his hardware store.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase firewood and pay for transport expenses.

loans.name: San Juanito Group

texts.es: En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Villa Adela, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal San Juanito, que recientemente se formó para acceder al préstamo, esta integrada por 7 mujeres y 1varón liderizadas por su mesa directiva, desarrollan su reunión ordenadamente, así la  presidenta es Teodora Q., Tesorera es Genoveva López y ocupando la cartera de Secretario de Actas está  Juan A., indican que formaron el grupo por la necesidad de contar con un capital de trabajo para mejorar sus niveles de ingreso, así todos tienen diferentes actividades económicas tales como la carpintería (elaboración de muebles), tejido de mantas, venta de carne de pollo, ropa, gorras, detergente y costura de mandiles (delantales). Esperan invertir el préstamo en sus negocios para hacer crecer el mismo.
texts.en:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Villa Adela, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal San Juanito, que recientemente se formó para acceder al préstamo, esta integrada por 7 mujeres y 1varón liderizadas por su mesa directiva, desarrollan su reunión ordenadamente, así la presidenta es Teodora Q., Tesorera es Genoveva López y ocupando la cartera de Secretario de Actas está Juan A., indican que formaron el grupo por la necesidad de contar con un capital de trabajo para mejorar sus niveles de ingreso, así todos tienen diferentes actividades económicas tales como la carpintería (elaboración de muebles), tejido de mantas, venta de carne de pollo, ropa, gorras, detergente y costura de mandiles (delantales). Esperan invertir el préstamo en sus negocios para hacer crecer el mismo. The communal bank San Juanito meets at one of Pro Mujer's regional hubs, Villa Adela. They recently formed so that they could get a loan. The 7 women and one man who make up the group's board help meetings run smoothly. The president, Teodora Q., the treasurer Genoveva L. and the secretary and minute-taker, Juan A. say they formed the group because they needed working capital to improve their income. They all work in different economic activities such as carpentry, blanket weaving, selling chicken, clothes, hats, detergent, and sewing aprons. They hope to invest their loan in growing their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 40-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their five children. Ibrahim has been working as a builder since 1992. Ibrahim requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time. 
Ibrahim is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work and he had experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: C4522 Ubumwe Group

texts.en:
Adiel N. is 29 years old and is married with three children. He is the president of a group called Ubumwe, which operates its business in the bustling Kimironko market. The primary activity of this group is fabricating, soldering and assembling doors, windows and some other items used in metal construction. This hardworking group has succeeded in this predominantly male business for five years now!

Ubumwe Group is requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their business through the purchase of some new metal equipment and supplies. They hope that this will increase the quantity of their products sold as well as attract new customers. If successful, they hope to earn more profits, which will allow them to build a more secure future for their families.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and supplies

loans.name: Wasim

texts.en: Wasim is a 30-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa. Wasim has been selling and producing aluminum since 2000. Wasim requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase an aluminum machine. This machine will help him cut the aluminum in a better and more precise way. This is the first time that Wasim has requested a loan. Wasim is speciA. in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had difficulty purchasing all the required tools. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase an aluminum machine.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 36 years old and is married with four children aged between 2 and 8 years. He lives in Kayonza district, approximately one and a half hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Samuel has been selling a variety of goods for the past ten years. He is a proven businessman and well-known in his community. The hours of his business require that he works from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Samuel is now requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company, which will allow him to expand his business. He will use the loan to purchase a larger variety of goods for sale which he knows his customers want but which he has not been able to provide. With this expansion, Samuel hopes to earn more profits than ever. With this profit, he will be able to build a stronger business and take better care of his young family.

loans.use: To purchase a larger variety of goods and to use as working capital

loans.name: C2690 Abumugisha Group

texts.en:
Osee M. is 47 years old and is married with six children and three dependents with ages between 3 and 14 years. Osee is the president of a group called “Abumugisha” which operates its business in Rwamagana, approximately an hour and a half drive from Rwanda's capital city of Kigali. This group has been successfully managing their pharmacy for the past eight years and are very experienced. They are also very committed, working twelve hour days, six days per week.

The members of this group are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their pharmacy. They will use the loan to purchase more medicines and supplies, which will result in increasing the number of customers as well as greater sales and profit (hopefully). If successful, they plan to reinvest in their business, pay school fees, and continue to build secure futures for their children.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of medicines and supplies

loans.name: Annastacia

texts.en:
Annastacia I. is a 28-year-old married mother of two children. She lives in Kiembeni in the coastal town of Mombasa. Annastacia owns a clothes store in Mombasa town and has been selling clothes for nine years.
 
Annastacia is borrowing her first loan from KADET and she plans to increase her stock of second hand clothes. Her main customers are the residents of Mombasa.

She hopes to diversify her business to include selling women's bags and shoes in the future.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy second hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Marta Eugenia

texts.es:
La microempresaria: Marta Eugenia B. Siú tiene 50 años de edad, es madre soltera tiene 4 hijos todos adultos, es abogada y administra un negocio de venta de comida y refrescos desde hace mas de 15 años. Este negocio era propiedad de su mama (actualmente fallecida) desde hace unos 40 años y bastante reconocido en esta ciudad de Bluefields.

En el negocio de la señora B. se venden sorbetes, desayunos, refrescos naturales y gaseosas y comida a la carta. Además se venden queques para cumpleaños como otros productos complementarios para este tipo de actividades.

Sus clientes son habitantes de esta ciudad que por un lado llegan al negocio a consumir sus productos como también a realizar encargos principalmente de queques para cumpleaños y bodas.

La microempresaria B. esta solicitando  se le financie para comprar los siguientes productos:

2 Quintales de Azúcar a US 35 dólares cada quintal, 2 cajas de leche a US 45 dólares cada caja, 2 cajas de mantequilla a US 35 dólares cada caja, 80 libras de pollo a US 1.30 dólares cada libra, 3 cajillas de huevos US 30 dólares cada cajilla y 2 quintales de  harina a US 38 dólares cada quintal.
texts.en:
Marta, the micro-entrepreneur, is 50 years old, and a single mother with 4 children, all adults. She is a lawyer and has administered a business that sells food and soft drinks for over15 years. The business was the property of her mother (now deceased) for some 40 years and is well known here in the City of Bluefields.

Marta's business sells sherbets, breakfasts, natural and bottled drinks, and food a la carte. In addition, she sells birthday cakes and other complementary products for such occasions.

Her customers are inhabitants of this city who come to the business to consume its products as well as to place orders, principally for birthday and wedding cakes.

Marta is soliciting financing for the following products: 2 quintales of sugar at $35 per quintal, 2 cases of milk at $45 per case, 2 cartons of butter at $35 each, 80 lbs. of chicken at $1.30 per pound, 3 cases of eggs at $30 per case, and 2 quintals of flour at $38 per quintal.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY SUGAR, MILK, BUTTER, CHICKEN, EGGS, AND FLOUR

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. is 30 years old and is in the business of selling electrical goods in Mombasa's Kongowea market. He is married and has a daughter, Mercy. The family lives in Magongo in Mombasa.

Joseph was introduced to KADET by a friend recently and is now accessing his first loan from the lending institution to boost his business. He plans to buy radios and other electrical goods for sale at the Kongowea stalls. 

He hopes to grow into a leading supplier of electrical goods in Mombasa town in the future.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy radios and other electrical goods

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 27-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife. Ahmad has owned a small coffee shop since 2000. He also has a billiard table. Ahmad requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop and a new billard table. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.
Ahmad is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and his clients feel comfortable coming to his shop. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all he needed for his shop. Ahmad decided on this business because he learned it when he was young. In the future, he plans to improve his business and open a fruit and vegetable shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a new billard table.

loans.name: Mathilde

texts.fr: G. Mathilde est née le 16 Mars 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mathilde est mariée à HOUNZANDJI Bernadin, un soudeur. Le couple a trois enfants en charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Mathilde vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Sèmè-Podji depuis une dizaine d'année. Mathilde n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Mathilde vend de façon ambulante des bouteilles de tous genres. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Mathilde s'approvisionne. Mathilde a déjà sept ans d'expérience dans ce domaine. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir son activité, Mathilde sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Mathilde G. was born on 16 March, 1967, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Mathilde is married to Bernadin Hounzandji, a welder. The couple have three children in their care, of whom two are their own. Some of the children are in school. Mathilde has lived with her children and husband in Sèmè-Podji for ten years. Mathilde did not go to school. To meet her needs, Mathilde sells bottles of all kinds door-to-door. It is at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, that Mathilde gets her supplies. Mathilde has already gained seven years of experience in this area. She is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid her loans properly. In order to increase her working capital and enlarge her business, Mathilde is seeking a fifth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bottles

loans.name: Andrew Mulandi

texts.en:
Andrew is 29 years old and married with two children. He shows videos and offers video games at a fee to children in a small makeshift room in Kawangware. He has been in the business for about seven months now with a profit of about 7,600 Kenya shillings a month. 

He has never borrowed from another MFI and this is his first loan from KADET. He was introduced to KADET by a friend. He wants to use the loan to get a more spacious room and buy more household items and home electronics for sale. 

He hopes to expand his relatively new business to a level that can give him sufficient returns to support his family.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To get a spacious room for video shows and buy household items to sell

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en: Mhammad is a 55-year-old man who lives in Saida southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Mhammad has been working as a carpenter since 1980. Mhammad requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a machine for his work. This machine will help him improve his work. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time. Mhammad is speciA. in his work because he is good at his job since he has a lot of experience. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Mhammad decided on this business because he learned it when he was young. In the future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for his work.

loans.name: C 4560 Korankore B Group

texts.en:
Marie Claire is 42 years old and is married with four children aged between 7 and 20 years. An upstanding member in her community, Claire has been the president of a group called Korankore B since 2005. This group wholesales organic, tree-based charcoal. This is a competitive business that Korankore B has made a name for itself in and benefits from that reputation. The hours of the business are from early in the morning up to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

The members of this group are requesting their first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders for the purpose of expanding their business through purchasing more charcoal wholesale at better prices. With this loan, they hope that their life will change progressively as they can make more money through their efforts and set aside some savings for their respective futures.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and supplies wholesale

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is 32 years old, married with five children with ages between 2 and 10 years. She also takes care of one dependent. She lives in northern province of Rwanda, a region of Musanze district where she has operated the business of selling traditional clothes.  Her business is a small one but well known in her community and she has a loyal customer base. The hours of her business require that she work from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Immaculee is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order purchase some new attractive clothing and material styles for sale as well as additional sizes and colors. With this loan, Immaculee hopes to attract more customers to her business and hopefully earn more profit in the process. Immaculee will save a portion of any profits earned as a major goal for her is to build a secure financial future for herself and her children.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods and to use as working capital

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb O. is a married man, 29 years old. His wife Susan Otieno is a business lady and they are blessed with one child. 

Caleb operates a welding business that has been in operation for two years in Kiembeni. He mainly serves the residents of Kiembeni and surrounding hotels by making metal doors and windows for them.

Caleb was introduced to KADET by a client and this marks his first loan from KADET. He plans to purchase metal bars that he will use in his welding station.

In the future, he hopes to own fabrication and metal works machines to help him stabilize his business.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase metal bars.

loans.name: Nassim

texts.en:
Nassim A. is 39 years old and married. Her family lives in the outskirts of Mombasa in an area called Changamwe. Nassim hawks clothes and supplies them to selected customers in Changamwe. She has been doing this for the last four years and she has been successful so far.

She learned about KADET through a friend and this is her first time to borrow money. She intends to purchase more clothing to sell especially during this peak Christmas season.

In the future, she hopes to own a clothes boutique.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sale.

loans.name: C 8869 Abakundumurimo Group

texts.en:
Odette is 41 years old and is married with two children with ages of 5 and 25 years. She lives in the Western Province of Rwanda, which is approximately three hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here Odette is the president of a group called “Abakundumurimo”.

This group has operated a business of selling a variety of drinks and food supplies for many years; in fact, this is the twelfth successful year of business for them! This bustling enterprise employs people who work from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday.

After paying back their first loan in full and on time, this group is now requesting its second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their business. They will use the loan to purchase additional and larger quantities of food supplies and drinks needed by a number of their customers.

With this loan, and assuming the members of this group are successful, they hope to earn enough profit to allow them to buy their own warehouse for their business. They dream of providing a much better standard of living for their families

loans.use: To purchase more sorgham and supplies

loans.name: Rita

texts.fr: N. Rita est née vers 1960 à Parakou, au Nord du Bénin. Rita est mariée à PALAGA Bernard, un chauffeur. Le couple a quatre enfants en charge, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Rita vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Lokokoukoumé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 17 ans. Rita assure avec son mari les dépenses de la famille. Rita a fait seulement le cours primaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Rita vend des vêtements de même que des sous-vêtements au carrefour Dégakon à Cotonou. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo que Rita s'approvisionne. Rita mène comme activité secondaire, de l'eau sucrée localement appelée "Chakpalo". C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Rita sollicite un septième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux faire face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
N. Rita was born around 1960 in Parakou, in northern Benin. She is married to PALAGA Bernard, a chauffeur. The couple has four children to support. Three of them are their own; all of them are in school. She has been living with her children and husband in Lokokoukoumé in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for seventeen years. Along with her husband, she ensures that family expenses are met. Rita has gone to primary school only. For a dozen years, she has been selling clothing, as well as undergarments, at the Dégakon crossroad in Cotonou. She acquires her goods from Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin, and from Lomé in Togo. Her secondary business involves sweetened water locally called chakpalo. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans. She’s requesting a seventh loan from ALIDé to augment her working capital and to cope better with more and more customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and undergarments

loans.name: Anthony Mutua

texts.en:
Anthony,  27, is married and has one child. He operates a butcher shop in Mlolongo shopping center where he sells beef, goat meat, and mutton. He has been in the business for seven years, and he earns a profit of approximately 13,000 Kenya shillings a month. His customers are from within the area and from Nairobi city.

Anthony has never borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by friends. He wants to use the loan to buy more meat to sell to his clients. He hopes to build his business to be the largest butcher shop in the area, and he also wants to buy a piece of land to build his home.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Buy meat for his shop

loans.name: God Time Group

texts.en:
Bendu M. is a leader of a group called "God time." This group has five borrowers. Bendu, 32, is married and has three children between the ages of 2 and 9.  One is in kindergarten and one is in second grade.

Bendu dropped out of school in the sixth grade because of poverty. She lives and work in the VOA community, which is north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia. She sells food stuffs such as oil, pepper, rice, and so forth that she buys wholesale and then resells at retail prices to the residents of VOA. She has been running this business for three years, and she hopes to improve her shop in the future. Bendu talks to her customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. 

She started her business with LD1000.00 that was given to her by her husband. Bendu needs this loan to purchase more rice, oil, pepper and so forth to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education so they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy rice, oil, pepper and and other food items

loans.name: Ann Gichugu

texts.en:
Ann is a 56-year-old widow with six children between the ages of 19 and 33. Ann runs a primary school in the Kitengela area of Kenya. She has been in the business for one year now, and she makes a profit of about 17,000 Kenya shillings a month. 

She has never borrowed from an MFI; this will be her first loan from KADET. She will use the loan to buy school textbooks and more seats. She hopes to expand the school to enroll more children.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve the living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy textbooks and seats for the school

loans.name: Lovette Angelita

texts.es:
La microempresaria: Lovette Angelita Martínez D. tiene 57 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos, todos son mayores de edad, es profesora y tiene desde hace mas de 15 años un comedor y hospedaje ubicado en el barrio central de esta ciudad de Bluefields.

En su negocio tiene varios cuartos los cuales son utilizados principalmente por pobladores originarios de las comunidades quienes llegan a esta ciudad por razones de comercio o por asuntos personales y se ubican en este hospedaje por su ubicación contiguo al muelle municipal lo que le facilita al momento de abordar una embarcación y poder regresar a su comunidad de origen.

Ala vez les ofrece el servicio de comida los tres tiempos aprovechando que estos no tienen familiares en esta ciudad y requieren de este servicio, sin embargo los cuartos del hospedaje necesitan seguridad ya que son de madera y en los últimos meses ha estado reparándolos poco a poco ya que las ganancias no le permiten hacer una gran inversión, por tal razón esta solicitando financiamiento para comprar parte del material que requiere para remodelar sus cuartos y garantizar mejor atención a sus clientes.

Necesita comprar: 10 Bolsas de Cemento a US 10 dólares  cada bolsa, 60 unidades de  bloques a US 1 dólar cada uno, 2 metros de arena a US 24 dólares cada metro, 3 quintales de varillas hierro a US 80 dólares cada quintal, 2 metros de  piedrín negro a US 75 dólares cada metro  y  2 libras de alambre de amarre a US 1 dolara cada libra.
texts.en:
Lovette Angelita Martínez D. is a 57 year old small businesswoman. She has three grown children. She is a teacher. For over 15 years she has had a dining room and a hostel, which is located in the central neighborhood in the city of Bluefields. In her business she has several rooms, which are primarily used by the inhabitants of other communities who come to this city for business or for personal reasons. They stay in this hostel because of its location, which is by the municipal dock. That makes it easy to get on a boat to be able to return to the community they are from. She offers three meals a day, taking advantage of the fact that the lodgers do not have family in this city and require this service. Nevertheless, the rooms in her hostel need security. They are made of wood, and in the last few months she has been repairing them little by little. Her earnings do not allow her to make a large investment. That is the reason that she is asking for a loan to buy part of the material she needs to remodel the rooms and guarantee better service for her customers. She needs to buy: 10 bags of cement at $10 US per bag, 60 units of blocks at $1 US for each one, 2 meters of sand at $24 US per meter, 3 “quintales” (100 pounds) of metal bars at $80 US per quintal, 2 meters of black gravel at $75 US per meter, and 2 pounds of wire at $1 US per pound.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cement, blocks, sand, metal bars, black gravel, and wire

loans.name: Tanjong Comfort

texts.en:
Tanjong Comfort has been a contributing member of GHAPE since 2006. She is currently hoping for her fourth loan as she has made great progress since she first joined. She is hoping for a loan in order to expand the number of items she sells through her food stand. She would like to add flour, seeds, palm oil, bananas, and cocoyams to the items she currently sells. Tanjong considers her business will succeed because she has always experienced strong sales through her food stand. She expects the expansion of products available at her location will strengthen her offering as well as strengthen her relationship with her customers.

Tanjong is an enthusiastic individual who, despite severe hardships, has managed to maintain a positive outlook on life. Tanjong’s most difficult loss was the recent passing of her husband. She felt a deep pain at the loss of her spouse and leaned on her friends and family during her difficult time of mourning. She considers the best manner by which she can contribute to her community is to provide healthy food as well as the option of a nice room in her house for a reasonable rent.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables, fruit and palm oil for resale

loans.name: Esther Dadi

texts.en:
Esther, 37, is married and has two children. She runs a grocery shop where she sells fruits and vegetables. She has been in the business for about five years, and she makes a monthly profit of about 10,000 Kenya shillings. 

Esther has never borrowed from an MFI. A friend introduced her to KADET, and she is requesting a loan so she can buy more fruits and vegetables to meet the demand of her customers. She also wants to start selling clothes as a secondary business. This way, Esther will diversify her job.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve the living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables and venture into selling clothing

loans.name: Daniel Mungui

texts.en:
Daniel is married to Judy and they have three children. Their children, Elizabeth, Shine and Christine, are ten, six and two years old, respectively.

Daniel was introduced to KADET by existing groups and he is requesting his second loan. His primary source of income is rental rooms but he also has been running a retail shop for eight years. The client's area of business is densely populated with middle class residents as the main customers. He has applied for a loan, which he will use to add to the milk that he supplies to other shops in his area of business. With the extra profits, Daniel will purchase another plot of land and build more rental rooms. 

Daniel hopes to expand his business from retail to the wholesale level and he describes himself as  determined, hardworking and focused.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase the stock of milk supply.

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr: H. Léonie est née en 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve et mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Léonie vit seule avec ses enfants au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou depuis 10 ans. Seule Léonie assure les charges de la famille. Léonie a été à l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Léonie vend des mèches et des produits pour cheveux dans sa boutique à son domicile. Léonie vend également des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Léonie s'approvisionne. Léonie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de 8 crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue de renforcer son activité surtout à l'approche des fêtes, et de mieux satisfaire ses clients, Léonie sollicite un neuvième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Léonie was born in 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widow and the mother of two children who are both in school. She has been living alone with her children in the Finagnon district in Cotonou for ten years. She alone ensures that family expenses are met. Léonie has attended secondary school. To provide for herself and these two children of her, she sells hair extensions and hair products in the shop in her home. She also sells mobile phone recharge cards. She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who has already benefited from eight ALIDé loans, which have been repaid. With the aim of bolstering her business, especially as the holidays approach, and satisfying her customers further, she’s requesting a ninth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and phone cards

loans.name: Veronica Kanini

texts.en:
Veronica is a single mother to one child Paul, eleven years old. Veronica has been running a green grocery business for ten years in a highly populated area within the Nairobi eastlands area.

The client was introduced to KADET through existing clients and has no previous credit history. She has applied for a loan which she shall use to add stock of vegetables to her store. With the extra profits Veronica will stock cereals.

Veronica hopes to educate her child to the highest level and she believes she is hardworking.

About KADET:  
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to add stock of vegetables.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 42 years old, married, and has 3 children. To earn a living, she sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to expand her business in the future by having a maternity home. She hopes for a loan amounting to NGN 50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She is a hardworking woman and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for her shop

loans.name: Elizabeth Maloba

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 44-year-old married lady with five children. She sells fish, fruits and vegetables to her customers in Zimmerman estate in Nairobi. She has been in the business for a period of fifteen years, earning a monthly profit of approximately 8,000 Kenya shillings. 

She has never borrowed from another MFI before. She and some of her business friends formed a group and visited the KADET office to borrow loans.  She wants to use her loan to buy more fish, fruit and vegetables to sell in order to meet her clients' demands. 

She hopes to educate all her children to the highest level, build her own house, get more income and buy a deep freezer for storing fish.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more fish and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk  for resale

loans.name: Esperanza En La Fe1 Group

texts.en: Lavidieu Otilus wants to start a business selling clothes to support his two little children. He needs help with a loan to do this, and you can help him improve his life.

loans.use: To buy clothes and sell them

loans.name: Sergio

texts.es:
El socio SERGIO pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA”, es natural de la provincia de Calca del departamento del Cusco.  La ciudad de Calca esta a una hora de la provincia de Cusco.
  
El socio es conviviente tiene cuatro hijos tres mujeres y un varón. Los hijos mayores estudian en el colegio nivel secundario y el menor primaria.  

El trabaja como chofer hace servicio de transporte en la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado y tiene un negocio familiar de venta frutas al por mayor y menor en el mercado modelo de Calca. La fruta lo trae de la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado.     

El socio requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de venta de frutas como papayas, plátanos, naranjas mandarinas, mangos, piñas etc.    
 
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Serio is a member of the Virgen Asunta Communal Bank. He is from the Calca province in the Cusco department. The city of Calca is one hour from the province of Cusco. He is in a common law marriage, and he has four children, three girls and a boy. The older children are in high school, and the youngest is in primary school. He works as a driver providing transportation service in the city of Puerto Maldonando. He also has a family business of selling fruit wholesale and retail in the Modelo Market of Calca. He brings the fruit from the city of Puerto Maldonado. He needs a loan to increase capital in his business of selling fruits like papayas, bananas, oranges, tangerines, mangoes, and pineapples, etc. He is grateful for this opportunity, and he promises to make his payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more fruit to distribute in more cities in Cusco

loans.name: Cosme

texts.fr: S. Cosme est né en 1958 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Cosme est marié et a 5 enfants en charge, dont quatres sont ses enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. C'est depuis 27 ans que Cosme réside au quartier Dandji à Cotonou. Cosme vit avec ses enfants et sa femme. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Cosme a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Depuis une trentaine d'année, Cosme exerce le métier de soudure à Finagnon à Cotonou. Cosme s'approvisionne à Gbégamey, à Cotonou. C'est un ancien client de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue de renforcer son activité pour être plus performent et satisfaire plus ses clients, Cosme sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Cosme was born in 1958 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. He is married and has five children to support. Four of them are his; all of them are in school. For 27 years, he has been residing in the Dandji district in Cotonou. He lives with his children and wife. The couple provides for the family jointly. Cosme has attended secondary school. For thirty years, he has been working in the trade of welding in Finagnon, in Cotonou. He gets his supplies in Gbégamey, in Cotonou. He is a previous ALIDé client who repays his loans. With the aim of bolstering his business, to be more efficient, and satisfying his customers further, he’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric grinder

loans.name: Anye Laurence

texts.en: Laurence is married, though he and his wife are not currently living under the same roof. He has two children and lives in Ntualam, Cameroon. Laurence and his entire family are living in a house with two rooms. Laurence has had to overcome some challenges in life such as taking care of his children, especially as he is separated from his wife, paying school fees for his children, the death of his father, and ill health. Laurence sells chopped wood and raises livestock. He plans to invest this loan in buying wood, pigs and goats. Laurence has been a member of GHAPE since 2001 and this will be his seventh time to receive a loan. He has been quite successful in the past with his business due to its location and his reasonable prices. Also, with his experience, he is now earning good profits from his business. Part of Laurence’s profits from this loan will be used to take care of his children, buy necessities for the family, and give them good medication whenever they are sick. He will also reinvest some profits back into his business. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase livestock and firewood for resale

loans.name: Feature Treasure Group

texts.en:
Dan Dada C. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called Feature Treasure. He is 22 years old and single without any children.
He is an 11th grade student who is fending for himself because of poverty. Dan lives in the VOA community, north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia.
His business is the sale of kerosene. He buys kerosene from wholesalers and sells at retail to residents of VOA, north of the capital Monrovia, Liberia.
He has been running this business for three years, and hopes to have a petroleum station in the future. Dan talks to his customers in a good manner in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. He started selling with LD4000.00 that was given to him by his uncle. Dan needs this loan to purchase more kerosene to improve his business. He dreams of getting a higher education and building a house.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Pauline Awino

texts.en: Pauline Awino O. owns Kiowang Investment where she sells cosmetics, detergents, cooking oil, flour, salt and sugar to walk-ins and local customers. She has run this business for the last six years.  Her business is located at Manyatta market (local market) and challenges are strong competition and fluctuating demand.  She is using the proceeds of the KES40,000 loan to buy cosmetics and beauty products.  In the future, she wants to be a wholesaler and educate her children.  Pauline is married with three children and describes herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and beauty products.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Victoria M. from Tukuyu, married with four children between the ages of 1 and 20.  Victoria, who has been running a crops  business since 2007, works 9-12 hours per day, six days per week, earning about 100 USD per month.  She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk for her enterprise, and in the future she plans to open a new business. Victoria thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for business

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is married with six children. She lives Ntaricon, Cameroon. Marie and her entire family are currently living in a house with five rooms. Marie had to overcome some difficult challenges in her life, such as inadequate funding to pay her children's school fees, bad produce from farms and ill health. This has made life tough for Marie.

Marie currently sells shoes and poultry to make a living. She is requesting a loan in order to buy shoes and chickens for resale. This would be Marie's third loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2007. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to the location of her business, and her reasonable prices. Also with experience, she is now having good profits from her business.

Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication when ever they are sick.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: The purchase of shoes, chickens and livestock feed for resale

loans.name: Christone

texts.fr: H. Christone est née en 1975 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à GONOUVE Marcellin, un tailleur, Christone a en charge cinq enfants, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Lokokoukoumé dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji depuis 6 ans. Christone vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Christone n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis cinq ans environs, Christone vend des divers (boîtes de conserves, couscous, pâtes alimentaires, sardines, riz, haricot, condiments de sauce, etc.)à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Christone s'approvisionne. Christone est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de réunir suffisamment de fonds pour agrandir davantage son activité, Christone sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Christone was born in 1975 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to GONOUVE Marcellin, a tailor, she has five children to support. Four of them are her own; all of them are in school. The family has been living together in Lokokoukoumé in the community of Sèmè-Podji for six years. She works in aid of her husband to meet family expenses. Christone sells a variety of goods (canned foods, couscous, pasta, sardines, rice, beans, sauce condiments, etc.) out of her home. She acquires her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans. To augment her working capital and to gather sufficient funds for enlarging her business further, she’s requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of canned tomatoes, 2 sacks of rice, and some condiments for making sauces

loans.name: Emprendedoras Group

texts.es: Venta de frutas, jugos, verduras, ropa y tención de tienda de barrio son los diversos negocios de las integrantes del grupo Emprendedoras, que se reúnen cada dos semanas en el Centro Focal Senkata. Se agruparon por la necesidad de incrementar su capital de trabajo, algunas comprando mercadería, otras comprando insumos. Un claro ejemplo es Alejandra M. casada y madre de 5 niños, que en el pasado había trabajado con Pro Mujer, integrando otro grupo, pero ahora ha vuelto para formar parte de este grupo, porque además del crédito le gusta el ahorro y la atención en el consultorio. Alejandra desde muy pequeña se  dedica a la venta de fruta, en un inicio  ayudando a su madre y ahora  dueña de su propio negocio y piensa invertir el préstamo comprando uva y manzana, ella vende en la zona Máx. Paredes  de la ciudad de La Paz, en un carrito y adquiere su mercadería en la zona El Tejar de la ciudad de La Paz porque es económico.
texts.en:
Members of the Emprendedoras (Enterprising Ones) group are involved in a variety of activities, such as: sale of fruits, juices, vegetables, clothing and tending to neighborhood general stores. They meet every two weeks at the Senkata communal bank. They formed in order to increase their working capital, some to buy merchandise, others to buy ingredients. A clear example is Alejandra M., married with 5 children, who in the past had worked with Pro Mujer in another group, who has returned now to be part of this group because, in addition to the loans, she likes the savings and the care at the health center. Alejandra, from a very young age, has sold fruit; first, as a helper to her mother, and now as owner of her own business. She intends to invest the funds buying grapes and apples. She sells from a little vending cart in the Máx. Paredes area of the city of La Paz and she gets her merchandise in the El Tejar area of the city of La Paz because it is less expensive there.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise (grapes and apples).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials in bulk for business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for her business

loans.name: Sirri Maria

texts.en:
Sirri Maria is married with eight children. She lives Alabukam, Mankong, Cameroon. Maria and her entire family are currently living in a home with seven rooms.

Maria had to overcome some significant challenges in life such as inadequate funding to pay her children's school fees, ill health and the passing of several relatives. This has made life for her difficult but she is hopeful for her future based on her children and her small business. Maria currently sells meat for a living. Should she receive a loan, she plans on putting the funds towards buying a cow.

This would be Maria's seventh loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 1998. She has been quite successful in the past with her business which she attributes to her location and her reasonable prices. To date she has enjoyed good profits from her business but is hopeful for additional growth.

Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchasing meat for resale

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk
